content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												As a developer, what would you do when your game is loved by a dedicated fanbase, but mired in dislike for it's stifling DRM? You make a stand alone expansion that is six times the original game and streamline it for an excellent online experience. Good guy Relic. Real Time Tactical Roleplaying Game. That is how I would describe Dawn of War Retribution. It is focussed on character building, and using special abilities to clear obstacles and objectives. Clearning these obstacles rewards you with gear and other sweet loot to use and to adapt to circumstances. However, unlike the original Dawn of War 2, this one does it with more than just the Space Marines. This time round the campaign is open to the zealous Space Marines, the dogmatic Imperial Guard,  the enigmatic Eldar, the barbaric Orks, the horrific Tyrranids and the eldritch Chaos Marines. Each faction proceeds through the same story and events, but does so for a different purpose. The Space Marines need to clear their name, as their chapter master allegedly has fallen to Chaos, while the Eldar pursue the same cause to prevent their planets from being destroyed by the Inquisition. The Orks just want to fight and the Tyrranids hunger. The voice acting in the game is top notch and delivers the ruminations of each character with gusto and panachel; Slightly over the top, yet in tune with the material. The overal experience is entertaining and diverse, allowing for many hours of gameplay on your own, or with a friend. The game also features and extensive multiplayer component to go head to head. It plays like your ordinary RTS, but allows for so much customisation in regards to outfits and paintjobs. You might be forgiven for thinking that Valve made this game. The overal experience is a fast paced stratagem, with more focus on skirmishes between parties than massive clashes between armies. The last mode, and perhaps the most entertaining is Last Stand. In this mode, you and two others try to fend off twenty waves of enemy hordes with customised hero units. The mode is amazing for its many options and rewarding gameplay. No matter how far you come, the game will always reward you with points or items for your effort. Get a friend to two and tackle this beast. You will be entertained.I could go on to muse this game for another while, but if you're not really into the compact rts style, or Warhammer for that matter, then this game might not be your cup of tea. It can also get a bit boring after five campaigns. Especially the more human oriented races do feel a bit stale after a while. What? Of course not! Humans? Stale? Art thou mad? Humanity shall prevail. The Emperor wills it. The day that Chaos rules the minds of men shall never come. Stand fast fellow warrior and join us in the eternal battle against the foul beings that the vile warp hath unleashed. Forget you money; human lives are the Emperor's currency. So spend it well, and pay your debt to his Greatness!

Posted: January 26, 2016
												the singleplayer campaign isnt too good but its also not very bad. repetitive levels though and a rather weak and short told story. still i had fun to hunt the achievements there and to play it with friends in coop-mode. bit annoying bugs there were, even before the migration from winlive to steam when achievements wont unlock, i had to play some races multiple times to trigger them. the multiplayer is really great though. its just a good concept to ignore base building (which is boring in my opinion) and focus on the micro management of your army fighting for points. i like the great variety of units and abilities which allow different playstyles and lots of strategies. the biggest issue is and was the small player count in the multiplayer mode, still you find and found enough to pretty much always get some games going.the greatest mode for me is the last stand mode, i dropped hundreds, if not thousands, hours into leveling my heroes and playing for score or just for fun or to help others. it never gets old and you can always jump back in after some time. you will always find players there immediately.really poor is the support from relic though. the game still has quite a few bugs, especially after the migration from winlive, where the game started, to steam. this update really put a lot of new bugs in the game and took some good functions away and more or less was left in this state.there is also a so called elite mod, which truely most veteran multiplayer gamer play today. its different balanced and features some more units and even a new faction. personally i dont like the balance there and prefer the balance in the original game. it ever and ever gets modified which maybe has a charme in its own, so you can adjust yourself ever again. after all superb game. im hoping on dow 3. but i dont have great confidence in relic when i see all the balance mess they made in coh2.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												INTRODUCTION:Dawn of War II: Retribution is the third and final expansion to the Dawn of War II titles. (Also see my Reviews for Dawn of War II and Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising).The story takes place after the events of Chaos Rising where Gabriel Angelos and his followers were labeled as renegades by their own Chapter Master Azariah Kyras. With the Tyranid invasions, Ork assaults, Chaos Incursions and Eldar Raids, the Imperium has had enough and has now sent the Inquisition to wipe Sub-sector Aurelia from the Galaxy. The player assumes the role of Captain Apollo Diomedes of the Blood Ravens Honor Guard in his quest to uncover the truth about his Brothers and the Chapter Master he serves.PROS:+ More Factions in the Singleplayer Campaign: -  It is refreshing to see that Relic decided to bring back their old formula where other factions are now playable. This includes, Orks, Eldar, Chaos, Imperial Guard and Tyranids. No Tau though.+ Active Multiplayer Scene: - I normally don't care about Multiplayer in games but I found it very impressive that there still exists a very active online multiplayer community. Last Stand is always fun to play.+ Imperial Guard: - This faction is the latest addition to the multiplayer / skirmish mode and is very fun to play. Well balanced in my opinion and has added new and interesting characters with likable personalities like Sergeant Merrick.+ Hero Replacement: - You can now field special Honor Guard units rather than the Hero units you are given. Example: Leave Scout Sergeant Cyrus and deploy a Terminator Honor Guard Squad instead.CONS:- Dumbed Down Action RPG Element: - What made the Dawn of War II Campaign unique was its RPG elements. It was seriously disappointing to see it virtually stripped to its bare minimum with only 10 levels as the cap and severely limited wargear selections.- Poor pathfinding: - Some of the larger vehicles will literally block your army from passing through and will do some really strange movements when it tries to make room for them to pass through. This will result in a very disorganized troop movement specially in some of the smaller maps, or maps with very narrow bottlenecks.- Short Campaigns: - As a whole, the entire campaign is long if you play through all the factions, but individually, they are shorter than the previous titles with some very weak or hastily put together plot.- Some unresolved bugs: - At the time of this review the game should be 3 years old but still I encounter bugged missions or bugged units and sometimes out right crashes. Not game breaking but this should have been fixed a long time ago.CONCLUSION:GOOD EXPANSION BUT I WOULD RECOMMEND PLAYING THROUGH THE ORIGINAL GAME AND CHAOS RISING FIRST. Retribution adds new factions and units to the game both in Single and Multiplayer, it gives back life to the series with a lot of interesting new characters and story. It does suffer from a rather weak campaign when compared to the original, but makes up for it in a fun multiplayer experience.New players might enjoy this more for the multiplayer / skirmish rather than the story so I recommend new players to try the original Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising first or even the first Dawn of War game if they want to be invested in the Story.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Gameplay wise, it has deviated a bit from the traditional Dawn Of War 2 campaigns in favour of a more Dawn Of War - Dark Crusade like meta campaign. You can now choose between Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, Chaos and the Imperial Guard. The campaigns are the same for everyone, however each race has their own agenda. But the goal of every race is to eliminate Azariah Kyras. That means even though the campaign feels redundant, it is refreshing to be able to change tactics and play the campaign as other races.Retribution also brings some diversity to the campaigns, such that unlike the previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, you can now further diversify your forces by replacing your regular deployable hero units with other honor guard units, depending upon your play style or according to what sort of opposition you expect to face in the campaign. You can also now field a larger number of squads by capturing Relay Beacons (or equivalent for races other than the Space Marines) and call in additional squads or vehicles subject to the amount of Requisition you have captured during your battle. This makes your campaign similar to a skirmish game albeit with campaign like objectives.You can also gain traits for your hero units faster since you get a guaranteed trait every time you level up, unlike previous Dawn Of War 2 installments, where you have to level up 2-3 times before you get a trait.Though I feel its somewhat inferior to DOW2 and Chaos Rising story-wise, it is nonetheless interesting to see how the story ends for the Blood Ravens in the Space Marine campaign (which I believe is canon for this series).

												When I was 10, I asked my dad for a bb gun, I'm fairly certain he said no at that very moment, but being 10 I didn't hear him, and went around putting fliers from toys r' us in all of his stuff ala Christmas story with bbguns circled,well come christmas I did not recieve a bbgun.I got Warhammer Fantasy Battle.I looked at my dad, and he just laughed, and told me something like go playI did.I don't think to this day he realizes what he gave me.For inside was the warhammer rule book, and this contained not only the rules of playing the first versions of warhammer tabletop, but also the stories and art of warhammer.I was instantly enthralled, blood, violence, betrayal, sacrifice, crazy insane heroes, epic battlesskip ahead to my discovery of 40k and the fleshing out of the warhammer universe and story led me to consume the books, and art of the universe, my world has never been the same, I gave up Christianity because Jesus couldn't hold his own against Khorne, I mean really, Peace be with you? Lame.now I'll actually get to  DOW2:Retribution,Take the massive epic scale of warhammer, condense it down, down to small unit tactics, and you get  to the very heart of Warhammer, the tales of Individual squads and heroes taking part in the struggle of the  Eternal Galactic War,Every race is  balanced to a T, what at first appears to be a very limited set of units, and heroes, actually becomes an incredible and fluid tactics game, the ebb and flow of battle, the constant tug of war, ambushes, assaults, defenses,  last stands,  the epic clashes of heroes, and dread warmachines,  This is hands down, the best multiplayer Warhammer Game, it captures a very beautiful piece of this amazing universe and brought it to new life for me.Blood for the blood god, and skulls for the skull throne!

												This game is everything you could want from a Warhammer 40k RTS. It functions just like company of heroes, probably because theyre both made by relicOverall this is a wonderfull game to get if you like warhammer 40k. Theirs 6 factions to play as, each with its own unique machanics and play style, The Space Marines, The Imperial Guard, The Eldar, The Tyranids, Chaos, and my personal Favorite, The Orkseach faction has 3 different commanders you can deploy and the game is very well balanced, the sories are decent, and fun, but sometimes lacking depthMultiplayer is the key feature of this game, as it is the most fun you'll have. Stand against an ork waaaahg, or a tyranid invasion, or fight against the ruinous powers as the guard or the angels of death. The games are just long enough, and the learning curve isnt too severe if you know how to play an RTSThe Elite mod for this game has kept the community alive, as it rebalences the game, adds new units and another faction (The Grey Knights) and is updated frequently. The community for it holds monthly tournaments, has a number of game casters, and is overall a great communityPros+ 6 differnt factions that are very distinct from one another in how they play+ Lots of maps and worlds to choose from+ Graphics are pretty good+ Lots of different units for every army, as well as commanders+ good resource managment+ Multiplayer is amazing+ campaigns are pretty fun+ Elite mod has completely taken over as the official support and keeps the game alive+ AI is decently challanging+ Lots of solid DLC that isnt stupidly expensive and can easily be forgone if you dont want themCons- Only 2 multiplayer modes- Only can have 2 teams in multiplayer, so no massive 6 army free for alls, which was a wasted oportunity in my opinion- No more official support as THQ doesnt exist anymore- Controls are a bit wonky- Unit pathing can be weird at timesOn the whole, this game is well worth the mere $30 it asks for, and theirs plenty of DLC for it that is great, such as more wargear for you campaign commanders, more skins for multiplayer armies, and additional gear for the last standi give this game 10/10 Ork stormboyz rocketing into the imperial guard lines. Get the game, you wont regret it

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II: Retribution is an excellent RTS-style game where base-building itself is dropped, in favor of more strategic combat involvement. While this may seem initially like a dumbing-down from DoWI, the playstyle it encourages is more fast-paced, usually more aggressive, and leads itself to large armies splitting off across the map. This has ended up being a very fun way to play an RTS. The campaign has benefited from this style in that in place of a Commander unit, you can have up to four Heroes that are powerful (typically single-person) units with Wargear upgrades and stat boosts while in a mission. These heroes can be substitued for an Honor Guard unit, which is a stronger version of a standard army unit. While building an army is fun, I also had a blast clearing the missions with only my Heroes and their witty banter.Multiplayer has become faster, which is usually a plus, as it allows us to play more games, or to boot up a match when normally we couldn't. I enjoy that gameplay feels more aggressive, with players capturing Requisition Points and Power Nodes in order to increase the speed that accumulate resources to purchase army units, and with holding the Victory Points, in which you must hold more than your opponent for a period of time in order to win. This leads to a very active playstyle, where you're balancing defensive capabilities with offensive, and mobility with firepower. Nearly every unit has potential upgrades, either as stat increases or new weapons, allowing them to be good against, and bad against, different types of enemies. Something as small as purchasing a few Flamers will make your unit that much stronger with melee engages, and constantly staying one step ahead of your enemy in upgrades, or creating units to counter their build, will often be the deciding factor of whether you fall from grace, or rise in glory as a successful tactician. The Hero system also carries into Multiplayer, as you select from one of six races, then one of three Hero units per race. These Heroes have different skills and Racial Abilities, and encourage different playstyles. Similar to the Campaign, these Hero units can purchase Wargear ingame once they have met the requirements (per game, no carrying over), to grant higher stats and capabilities against different enemies.The Last Stand, also sold as an individual DLC package, is a great mode where three players try to survive, and conquer, 20 waves of enemies. Each player selects a Hero and their Wargear before entering queue, with seven different Heroes, and a LOT of Wargear options. Mirrors are possible, but do not generally affect gameplay, and will likely have different builds. Wargear is obtained through leveling up, where you gain experience points at the end of the game, or through special, sometimes difficult, achievements. Most Heroes have two achievement Wargear unlocks. The Last Stand is incredibly brutal, very unforgiving, and you may never beat it. Players have the ability to revive fallen teammates, though this immobilizes the reviver, and reduces their firepower greatly, easily causing their death as well. Also on the map are two Point Multiplying Nodes, similar in appearance to Power Nodes, that add a x3 multiplier to your team's score each. Certain types of enemies will try to capture these points for themselves. Each Hero is vastly different, and every team composition is as well, leading to immense replayability, especially if you haven't beaten either of the two maps yet... (It's always that blasted Wave 20! ;-;)Lore-wise this game is both engaging and genuinely gets the grimdark feel of the WH40k universe. As the story progressed, through the earlier two campaigns (DoWII and DoWII:Chaos Rising) and this one, I felt the tragedies come one after the other, and each victory feeling less and less impactful until you get that one killing blow that just brings everything you've done all together, and you can feel the weight just disappear off of your chest, and you sit back in the chair and let out this sigh of relief... until you are informed of another emergency happening almost immediately. It kept me on the edge of my seat with its grimdarkness, its surprisingly fitting comedy (especially playing as those 'ard Ork boyz), and my genuine interest in how it was going to play out. While a lot of people feel that the campaign is short, and it kinda is, it certainly isn't lacking in content or gameplay, and it was very fun.  Pros Cons   Engaging campaign, interesting and fitting characters, fun take on an RTS. Short campaign that may be a little lackluster if you haven't played the other campaigns in earlier games.   Fun multiplayer design that encourages constant action. May take a while to get into the mode as there is a lot to learn, and a lot to manage.   The Last Stand is a great mode with high replayability and a fun premise. May be repetetive, harder for lower-levels which may discourage Hero diversity, and one Hero is locked behind paid DLC. TL;DR: 9/10 A very fun game that successfully captured the essence of the WH40k universe, and gave me three fun modes to play. There is a modding community as well, keeping it alive, and encouraging its growth. I highly recommend it to any WH40k or RTS fan.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												9/10Campaign - Not as good as DOW2s and DOW2: CRs campaigns, but it makes up for this by allowing you to play the campaign through as all the races, Space Marines, Chaos Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, Tyranids and imperial guard. imperial guard is a new faction added in Retiribution we saw a little of in the previous 2 DOW2 games. overall the campaign was pretty decent.Last stand - Pretty much identical to the DOW2/DOW2:CR Last stand modes, adds one new map and a bunch more gear. Last stand is basically a horde mode, in an RTS. yes its interesting. there is a standalone game called "the last standalone" which is just the last stand mode.Multiplayer - Now i play the game mostly for the mutliplayer. i could make an entire essay about how the multiplayer is good, or bad.all you need to know is that unlike other RTS games like DOW1 or Starcraft 2, there is no base building. everything is produced from the HQ structure and unlocked via multiple tiers of tech, not much unlike other RTS games, just with no bas building. i would NOT reccomend the multiplayer if you are looking for an annihilate type of game, due to the lack of base buidling annihilate isnt a very popular mode in DOW2. HOWEVER, if objective based RTS play is your thing, awesome. DOW2: Retribution has some of the best objective based RTS play in pretty much any RTS i've played.due to the lack of base building the game is more about your units, how you use them, what they counter and what they're countered by, this game is extremely micro heavy as a result, and loosing one squad could potentially loose you the game. luckily there is the handy "Retreat" button which sends the unit back to the closest retreat point (usually your HQ) as fast as their legs can carry them.If you plan on playing the multiplayer competetively and are looking for actual challenging games with a competetive playerbase, i urge you to download "ELITE Mod" its basically a massive balance patch and content patch. the modding team are filling in for the lack of support relic has given this game since THQ died.ELITE Mod download ---> http://www.dawnofwar.info/thats about it. if it sounds interesting go for it.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2011
												In the mold of the Dark Crusade expansion for the original Dawn of War, Retribution allows you to play a campaign for each available faction. Unfortunately, the Risk-style campaign map present in Dark Crusade does not exist in Retribution. Instead, each faction plays an almost identical campaign on a set path, with the only major differences being the characters you use and what your characters say. While it's fun to play the new heroes from each faction, the campaign rapidly becomes repetitive. I played through the space marine and ork campaigns and had fun, but I couldn't bring myself to finish yet another campaign with a virtually identical story and identical missions.Not recommended.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Almost 5 years old and still going strong, Dawn of War II Retribution is a pretty fun game that'll keep you coming back for more with its addictive gameplay and strategic battle scenarios. It's not entirely perfect, but it can be a very enjoyable game for both old and new fans of the Warhammer 40K series.The Pros Awesome intro Six playable races (Space marines, Chaos, Imperial Guard, Eldar, Orks, and Tyranids) The Last Stand is the most addicting. Eight heroes(two of whtich are DLC) to choose from, 20 waves of enemies to fight off, and each of the two maps has special gimmicks to make the experience different. Can create custom color schemes for each race to use in Multiplayer and Last Stand Pretty cheap when it goes on sale Mods make it fun for those who play the Multiplayer mode by adding new units and increased pop cap (+300!) Final boss is fun to fight Lots of potential for a Dawn of War III You cam wage a massive WAAAGH! TYRANIDS!!!! The Cons  Campaign is repetative. Each race goes through the exact same missions with different dialogue, different commanders, different units, and different prologue and epilogue cutscenes. Some glitches have yet to be patched. Don't worry, there isn't that many Multiplayer is not as newb friendly as Last Stand. If you haven't played the first four Dawn of War games, stay away from it Tau Efficiency achievement 100 unit pop cap in Multiplayer makes it hard to get a good assault. Dark Eldar Archon and Sisters of Battle Canoness are not DLC heroes for Last Stand  :'(  Some DLC isnt worth it even when on sale, specifically the ones for Multiplayer that offer special color schemes that dont appear in Last Stand Space Marine and Imperial Guard campaign DLC is $2 whilst all other campaign DLC is $1 Space Marine ending is only canonical ending No third map for Last StandWhile it does have it's fair share of ups and downs, you can always be sure it will keep you coming back for more9.5/11 Here's to hoping they got something big planned for this game's 5th anniversary! -chugs fungus beer- WAAAAAAAAHG!!!!!!

content:
Posted: February 20
												Dawn of War II was a very different game from its predecessor; no base building, a prominent focus on smaller armies and objective play, and a generally more streamlined experience. While I definitely prefer the first game, I can see the appeal in the second, as none of the changes they made are necessarily bad. Dawn of War II: Retribution is the second standalone expansion to Dawn of War II, and has a pretty impressive feature list. A new race, new maps, and a super shiny, fully voice acted narrative campaign where we can finally play as the race of our choice instead of being saddled with the Blood Magpies. The single player is easily the best part of Retribution in my eyes, but this is primarily because I vastly prefer Dawn of War 1's style of multiplayer gameplay. It basically boils down to this: do you like traditional RTS? Play Dawn of War 1. Do you want a more modern experience, with tactics elements? Play Dawn of War II. Do you want neither? Well... go play Space Marine or something, I guess. I give this game 70 orky gubbinz out of 100.

Posted: November 3, 2014
												A wonderful take on RTS. Relic has once again made a stupendous game that combines great rts elements like cover, choke points, scouting, etc. And blends it with the intense micromangement of individual squads. The campaign is good, and well down, giving a good balance of missions to play through with different difficulties. However it lacks in preparing you for multiplayer, and the skills needed to really be able to compete against others. If your wanting a great rounded RTS, then pick this up, but be prepared for very hard, skilled opponents in multiplayer. There is no skill based matchmaking.4/5 Would pick this up again in a heartbeat.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												The last installment of Dawn of War II. Finally you can play as any race in the single player campaign. There is no carryover component from the previous games, and the game itself is standalone. The abilities and wargear are fairly fun to customize, and the game is not hard even on the highest setting. A second map was added to the multiplare arcade mode, which was harder waves than the first. There is a purchaseable arcade-mode DLC that adds a Tau crisis/broadside unit as a playable hero, which is very interesting.I guess overall this has to be my favourite series of all time, although I don't play this game at all anymore. Across the three games in this series I have logged almost 1000 hours of play, most of which was single player.Maybe it's a bad idea to review all three games under one title, but they are best viewed as parts of a whole. The vanilla game was really challenging when played on Primarch; there was an intricate re-deployment system that encouraged you to play every mission to the best of your ability, as well as a ton of wargear that wasn't guarenteed to drop at fixed points. Chaos rising was my favourite, offering maximal flexibility in squadmates, gear, playstyle and choices. Once the Chaos Rising patch is applied to the vanilla game, playing the vanilla part on hardest becomes really hard. The Corruption system in Chaos rising was great, decently complex, and have a bearing on the ending. Retribution was the easiest game out of the three, but you can play as any race you want and the ending is open-ended. Once again, Retribution does not require the first two games to play, and it has no carryover mechanic, although the storyline is officially continuous. If you don't like to play as space marines but like the single player aspect, just play Retribution.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												DOW2: Retribution is a disappointing step back from the previous Dawn of War 1 and even the base Dawn of War 2. The campaign of Retribution is a set of cloned missions identical for each race; unit customization and commander/specialty unit progression is too simple and lumpy compared to DoW2 vanilla. This cloned campaign does not even have the charm of the set of same missions from DoW1: Dark Crusade or DoW1: Soulstorm, because there is no aspect of base-building or sufficiently different strategic playstyles. While the overall storyline is not bad, the cloned nature of the campaign makes it utterly predictable after the first time you've played it, and the only virtue to playing through it again is to earn more achievements or to cheer on your second-favorite race.Gameplay in DoW2: Retribution is average; most units either suffer from a rock-paper-scissors balance mechanism, or are powerfully broken. Early game for a lot of races is slow and frustrating, as you must focus more on obtaining and securing resources than getting stuck in with your archnemesis. Whoever controls the power nodes wins. Between the focus on resource-gathering and the small size of the armies, this game could be reskinned to any other given RTS and you'd never know the difference; there is very little that sets this game apart as distinctly Warhammer 40K.Overall I can't give this game more than a 6/10. Relic and Games Workshop have quite a bit to make up for if they go through with DoW3.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												Building further upon the game's core concepts and ideas from Chaos Rising, this installment adds army building to the mix. The focus becomes less on your heroes and squads, and more on the overall plot, and its race/faction flavor. More linear than DoWII but still quite a bit of fun. Heroes gain more traits but the game becomes exceptionally stingy on wargear for them. Mission rewards offer you either 1 piece of wargear(in addition to the handful of items you find on a map) or unlocks/upgrades for your army units. Still not as good as Soulstorm or Dark Crusade but again a worthy title. Definitely worth it on sale, and I'll have to rate this one at 4 outta 5. I guess I really missed the base building aspects as I was looking forward to an RTS, which this still doesn't quite feel like. Retribution does, however, have a much higher replayability than Chaos Rising or core DoWII

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Warhammer 40,000 Dawn of War II – Retribution is a standalone "expansion" for Dawn of War II. I feel that "expansion" needs to be quoted because Retribution is an entirely standalone and complete game in itself, and ownership of either of the prior two Dawn of War games is unnecessary, and, conversely, if you own the previous games you don't get anything extra out of Retribution. Still, if they want to call it an expansion and give it a $30 price tag that's fine with me, because you'll get more gameplay out of this title than you will out of a lot of games that go for twice the price.f you're new to Dawn of War II, it's a bit different than your typical real-time strategy game. You don't build bases and collect resources, at least in the traditional sense, but rather command a small group of elite heroes in missions that have you moving from skirmish to skirmish with the occasional larger battle or boss confrontation tossed in to provide some extra challenge. While this type of gameplay may seem more akin to an action game, there's plenty of strategy at play. Different heroes and units have their strengths and weaknesses, and are more effective against some unit types than others. Managing cover and suppression effects are critical to success and sound tactics win out over brute force frontal assaults.This will be familiar to Dawn of War II veterans, but Retribution has changed things up a little for those of you who have played the first two games in the series. Rather than having squads attached to heroes, heroes are now all truly individual units. However, you can have squads of units accompany your heroes into a mission and even spawn in squads – subject to a population cap and resource costs. You can also choose to bring squads in place of heroes into missions and be compensated for the loss of a powerful hero by a higher population cap for the mission. Post-mission rewards are no longer limited to gear for heroes, but now include upgrades for the various squads available to your faction.Another thing that is different about Retribution is that it does not have "a" single player campaign – it has six. This is probably the one feature that Dawn of War II fans will be most interested in because it gives them the chance to control factions that were once only playable in the multiplayer game. The game features campaigns for the Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Chaos, Orks, Tryanids, and Eldar, each of which will probably take you at least six hours to make your way through. All told you're in the ballpark of forty hours here, territory rare outside of the RPG genre.The storylines of each campaign intertwine, and it's enjoyable to play through the conflict over the Aurelian subsector from each faction's perspective. While the factions do have their differences and each requires a slightly different approach to battle, when you get down to it the mission structure is pretty much the same in each campaign. You enter a map and must fight your way along its linear path to the main objective points, and then face a final boss, assault, or siege at the end of the path. Luckily the fundamental gameplay is enjoyable and enough mission variety is built within this framework to keep things from getting boring.The multiplayer game remains essentially unchanged, except that now all six factions are playable by anyone who buys Retribution regardless of whether or not they own any of the prior Dawn of War II games. Each faction lends itself to a different style of play, but they're well-balanced enough that you can be successful with any one of them. Multiplayer games focus on the capture and holding of control points, and like the single-player game are more tactics-focused than most strategy games – you have to do more with less rather than trying to overwhelm your opponents with masses of units. Although personally I had more fun with the campaigns because they are more story-focused and can draw upon the rich Warhammer 40K universe, the multiplayer game can certainly hold its own with any other real-time strategy game's multiplayer mode.Overall, the game features top-notch production values. The graphics are detailed and the animations capture the personalities of the heroes and units under their command. The voice acting is excellent, and the actors have the advantage of working with a great script. Retribution is an excellent value and a great game, and a no-brainer for those who played either of the previous games. And if you're new to Dawn of War II, Retribution is a great place to begin your experience.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
DAWN OF WAR II RETRIBUTIONDawn of War II Retribution is the second expansion and third edition of the Relic Entertainment RTS Dawn of War II (2009), following its predecessor Chaos Rising (2010). It takes the setting of the 41st millenium and lets the player experience it from a tactical combat perspective, controlling resources to build a better, more refined army than your opponent in order to claim victory.The game consists of three main elements as well as side features. These are as follows:MULTIPLAYERThe meat of the game for most players is the dynamic multiplayer which allows for intense tactical combat in 1v1 to 3v3, free for all and team free for all. The mainstay is the victory point control mode, a system whereby the winner is the first to drain their opponent out of victory points, whereas annihilation mode, where victory is the destruction of the enemy base, is slightly simpler. The multiplayer has many strenghts that have seen it through a prosperous lifespan:- Very in-depth tactical combat- Asymmetrical faction balance- Dynamic map design- Well balanced commander mechanics- Unique flow and pacing- Tactical combat that does not require lots of APM but perfect execution and follow-upHowever it harbours some flaws:- The unmodded game has certain poor balance choices- The ranked multiplayer is mostly dead due to stagnation and broken leaderboards- A few maps are almost unplayable in their lack of quality- The game has not received a balance patch since late 2011- The multiplayer is incredibly challenging and thus very hard to get intoThe game itself is very different to the one it followed up, Dawn of War, and this has turned many old DoW I players off it. I believe however the change is a necessary improvement to keep the franchise fresh, having been adapted from the Company of Heroes formula that proved to make a well established, well regarded RTS set in World War II.It is well known that the game has mroe depth with mod, so you shoudl look at these in particular:- Elite Balance Mod: http://www.dawnofwar.info- Codex Edition Mod: https://steamcommunity.com/groups/DoW2-CECAMPAIGNAlthough perhaps not as well designed as the vanilla game's campaignh, it allows for playthroughs with all factions and thus has replayability. Take the squad based combat to explore the story further in somethign that is worth looking at to grasp some mechanics.THE LAST STANDSimilar to a MOBA, this PvE aspect takes individual heroes in an arena and pits them against waves of enemy hordes. Especially fun with friends when you can combo each hero's abilities and work together, however sadly it only contains two different maps, though both play out differently.FEATURESArmy Painter: Allows you to customise your warriors before going into battle to choose pre-loaded schemes or make your own, including allowing players upload their own custom badges.Game History: Tracks all multiplayer stats so you can see just who and what you are losing to.World Builder: A piece of software I have found myself in for many an hour which gives you all the tools the developers had when making maps, incredibly enthralling and I recommend Duncan's guide for working out how to use it: http://www.dowreplays.net/DOW-II-Map-Making-Guide.pdfCONCLUSIONIt is an intensely tactical and strategic game with large depth and scope better with mods, but suffers from a thinning community and lack of developer support.If you like a challenge and an experience with something that is so unique, this is definitely worth ti if you can get in with the community.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												DOW 1 IS my favourite RTS game of all time. How does DOW 2 stack up? It's different... and, for me at least, dissapointing.The Good:- Gorgeous graphics - Decent OST and great sound effectsThe Bad:- It's a reskinned Company of HeroesCOH is about realism, squads trying to hold positions, while the enemy tries to flank. DAW is all about over-the-top glorious barnies. No matter how much I try to love DOW 2, Skirmish games are summed up in one word, FRUSTRATING.Instead of enjoying massive fights, 90% of the time you're playing cat and mouse, chasing rogue enemy units around the map as they steal your points. I'm no RTS God, but I can hold my own. This isn't challenging, it's just incredibly annoying and frustrating. You never get a chance to watch your units in action or enjoy a big fight, since your constantly chasing after the next little peon sneaking through the gaps of your defense to capture a point. When a big fight does happen, the enemy usually just retreats.It wouldn't be so bad if your unit cap wasn't so ridiculously low, there's no way to guard everything and you're constantly running around the map with incredibly slow moving units, fast moving air units would've helped.The retreat function, could've been a useful feature but totally spoils everything. You harm some units just a little, they retreat, while your units are chasing the retreating units down, the AI sends another small squad to steal a point on the opposite end of the map. Your attention goes towards them and you send another squad half way accross the map to chase them down. Your first squad follows the retreating units to their base and gets wiped out or you just retreat as they chase you to your base then they retreat... This isn't Dawn of War.Conclussion:My patern of playing DOW 2 over the years is, miss the graphics and theme, decide to play a Skirmish (not a fan of online play). Remember how incredibly annoying and frustrating the gameplay is. Stop playing and go back to DOW 1.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												Really, what can you say about Dawn of War 2 that hasn't already been said? It's a fantastic combination of so many things. The strategy of an RTS is there, with squad based combat, cover mechanics, a counter system, and tons of lore-friendly units to 40k while playing as any one of 6 main factions: The fearsome Space Marines, the swarming Tyranids, DA ORKS, the numerous Imperial Guard, the demonic Chaos Space Marines, and the cocky Eldar who totally didn't help to inspire a certain teleporting, hit-and-run Overwatch character who pretty much directly rips off the warp spider *cough* Tracer *cough*I've been a fan of Dawn of War and Warhammer 40k in general since middle school, playing the crap out of some tabletop 40k, the first DoW, all its' expansions, mods, etc, and the same goes for the series belonging to the second DoW game - this one. This is the most feature complete of the Dawn of War 2 series, having all the factions and a fully featured last stand mode, though it is lacking a little in the campaign department when compared to the base game and its' initial expansion - those campaigns were godlike and this one just sorta falters in comparison.That said, the multiplayer and last stand still hold up, with extremely well made RTS mechanics mixed expertly with Action RPG/Moba style mechanics in a way that NO WAIT PLEASE DON'T LEAVE ITS NOT WHAT YOU THINKYes the game has some Moba elements, and take it from a guy who isn't a big Moba fan, it pulls it off incredibly well. Each squad has a small set of upgrades you can add on and choose between as well as levelling up as they do combat, increasing health, damage, energy, etc. and making veteran squads and vehicles significantly more powerful than ones pumped out and sent to die, and as a result making unit survival a very important aspect of the game. Each unit has a mass range of abilities on their own, too, more often than not, helping them to be counters to various things in the game. No unit feels necessarily underpowered or useless - and even the largest units can feel fragile when countered properly.There's also the hero system - every game, you pick from one of 3 heroes to your respective faction. The heroes have a much higher level cap than the standard units (10 instead of 4), and have a much larger tree of upgrades to pick between and mix and match to find a loadout that suits your style, with higher tier weaponry, armor, and abilities not necessarily being better and instead being unique and useful in their own way. The hero also isn't an overpowered beast, meaning you still have to manage them the same way you would any other unit and hope they don't die and have to be revived.If you're here from Dawn of War 1, I'm afraid base building is gone mostly. There’s only basic defense building now. You also won't find massive armies in this game - the armies are significantly smaller as are the maps, but that doesn't necessarily translate to less fun. Take it from a Command & Conquer junkie, base building is great, but it isn't something that's missed in this game as there's enough strategic value added in through all the other new stuff that the removal of base building doesn't detract from the fun of the game in the slightest, nor does it necessarily speed the game pace up either - games can still slog on with your armies valiantly holding positions and fighting to the last man, and it's absolutely incredible with a huge amount of detail put into everything.I love Dawn of War 2. I love Dawn of War 1. It's that simple. This game doesn't REPLACE the first game, so if you have to pick between the two, there is no clear winner - with its' larger scale, base building, and incredible mods and content, the first Dawn of War will always be a fantastic game. But if you're looking for a smaller scale 40k RTS/RPG that's still incredibly fun and highly tactical, I'd recommend this game any day. I can't think of any other RTS that ever has or ever will do as good a job at feeling like a complete definition of what RTS can be than the Dawn of War series. You will, with certainty, get your money's worth.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Dawn of War 2 is an example of a good strategy about Space Marines. You can't have an enormously large army, only several tactical squads along with few units of Combat Heavy Machinery. Tactics and small groups of soldiers - those are the words about space marines (It's not a cannon meat like Imperial Guard afterall). But... that kind of gameplay doesn't appply to any other side of conflict though (except for Chaos, probably).I really liked approach in both MP and SP - a lot of customization options, ability to upgrade your squads the way you want to make them more effective for certain combat situations.Also, what makes this game great - realistic look of it. You don't have some cartoonish battle brothers of Blood Raven order, nor anime-styled eldars... Imperial Guard actually feel like common soldiers, rather than green plastic Army Men toys. (Not saying anything bad about original DOW)Retribution... well, I completely disaprove the idea of all races having the same darn campaign. It was ridiculous in Soulstorm, it is ridiculous here. What's the point of having other campaigns, if Space Marines version is canon anyways? (Still, ORC BOYZ RULZZZ! WAAAAGH!) And yeah... Diomedes sucks. I know, that he's always pinned there and a source of memes just like Boreale... But I'd rather play my old Force Commander or Gabriel Angelos (even though, that he'd be OP af, 'cause he can destroy legions of enemies with his badass look)AS for Last Stand - it sure great. Even though there is only one map - there is a huge variety of ways to play it. Different pieces of equpment, diverse characters of different races. Ain't it cool?P.S. (This review was made for all of DOW2 games - original, Chaos Rising and Retribution)8.5/10

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												If there's anything I love about this game, is that it stays true to most of the parts of the original Dawn of War games, the only differences are, which, I honestly see as improvements, for the most part:Removal of Morale system but addition of the Suppression system, this allowed you to slow incoming enemies and not only that, but have them under the manner of decreased accuracy.Knockback still existsSadly, kill sync animations aren't as common as they once were, but this also is a bit of an enhancement, as killsyncs can happen too almost too frequently in the original Dawn of War, where you can still attack the enemy doing it and, as a result, you can waste abilities when they're simply immune to the damage.Low and High cover still exists, thankfully, but bombed areas now serve as light cover, and even end up changing the floor texture of the map.While not all of the units from the first set of games exist, a large majority of them are still around, and even then, they're replaced with similar functioning units (Possessed Chaos Marines to Bloodletters, Kasrkins to Stormtroopers, Flash Gitz to Kommandos, etc.)Most infantry are less versatile, but as a result, have a bit more benefits. Soldiers can't be upgraded with every single thing.There is no more armory/blacksmith upgrades. Upgrades are done specifically for squads. Level up system also serves as a bit of a HP and Energy upgrade, too.Speaking of Energy, Energy system prevents massive spellspam then retreat.Voice Acting is wonderfully done, where some lines in Dawn of War I wasn't that well done, along with a bit of humor from characters' voice lines.Shiny paint for the armies now exists.The only bad improvements I've seen is;Vehicles easily overpower most sorts of infantry, even if they do have anti-vehicle specialties. Vehicles are easily the meta unlike in Dawn of War II, where you use both vehicles and soldiers to their best course of action.Population stays locked at 100, whereas the cap in Dawn of War is increased by base levels or sometimes, other means (such as building another certain building, for IG, building an Infantry Command post raises Infantry cap). This annoyed me, as I couldn't spread my group all over the map, and it made some battles very little instead of one huge battle.There is no longer base building, which removes the feel of having your own base to use as well as making things less 'homey'No more Listening Posts, this especially frustrated me.Retreat functions can be especially annoying, where even if ranged hits do land a shot, they do very minor damage, where melee does significantly larger damage (Vehicles at least can't retreat, however)Vehicle vs. Hero, guess who wins?Overall, however, this is still a very fun game, and I recommend trying it for it's humorous colors, well done voice acting, gameplay that still stays a bit true to the roots of the system.P.S. SEGA, please make Dawn of War III or more expansions that would include some more races, such as the Dark Eldar, and the Tau.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												!! do NOT buy if you intend to play 1v1, 2v2 etc. literally nobody is playing it. !!First to note: it is a very good game, lots (but somewhat repetitive) content, proper multiplayer functionality, chatrooms, customgames, different gamemodes: 1v1 up to 4v4 aswell as the last stand DLC's. Also the game Indirectly supports mods.Definately not worth its full price anymore, but on a sale the 15€~ for the Grand Masters Collection or such it can be worth it IF, as said, you dont intend to play the RTS part of the game aka the 1v1, 2v2, 3v3, 4v4 modes.I bought the "Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War II - Grand Master Collection" during a sale, according to steamcharts there are always around 1.000~ players online in DOW2 Retribution.You want to play Last Stand? Takes around 1 - 2min to find a game.You want to play some custom game? There will be generaly 2 - 6 custom games available for you to choose from, which depending on the needed player count will take 1 - 10min to start.You want to play CO-OP in the Campain but have no friends? Alone the default Chat-room has around 80~ ppl in it almost all the time.You want to play the RTS part of the game? I've spend 30, yes thirty, minutes total, at different times in the que for 1vs1 ranked mode. I found 1 single game in that time which lasted around 5min then my opponent left because he was loosing. There also is a "Leaderboard" showing the top ranked players, the rank 1 - 5 players all have around 400 total games, losses & wins combined. This game is from 2012. So yes, the RTS aspect of the game is as dead as it can be. If that does not bother you and its CO-OP or Last Stand you are after, go ahead and hf. However as the RTS part was the sole reason why I bought this game I returned it after figuring out that it was dead, but it is not to say that DOW cant still be worth its sale-money value if you dont care for the RTS part. The campain is the campain, which is a mixture of a RTS & RPG, just w/o base & unit building. While last stand is a grind-RPG basically on 2 different maps with 2 other players, where you have to choose from pre-designed "heroes" that level up and unlock new gear from the XP you gain after loosing a last stand game (you cant win that mode it just gets more difficult untill you wipe). Last stand could also be seen as a Tower Defence with movable Heroes to a certain degree.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2011
												One of my favourite RTS games.The campaign consists of a somewhat linear series of missions where you receive rewards in form of items and upgrades for your heroes and units.There are 6 different races (Space Marine, Imperial Guards, Tyranid, Chaos Marine, Ork and Eldar) which consists of four (4) heroes and several units.When playing the campaign you primarily use your heroes but you can create units and switch your heroes to an Honor Guard (A free and stronger version of regular units).In Multiplayer you can play from 1v1 to 4v4 and Free For All. There's ranked play and Custom Games. I mostly play the Campaign and The Last Stand but this is somewhat entertaining.There's also a game-mode called The Last Stand in which you choose a hero, equip him/her with Wargear and then fight against up to 20 waves of enemies. There are 2 maps which varies in difficulty.The game got good graphics and the gameplay is great but it's somewhat lacking in base building due to the fact that you only got your main building and the extra buildings you got available includes Turrets and sometime bunkers.It's not fully optimized but it runs close to perfect for me, my Graphic cards gets a bit warm in the menu which is weird but other than that it works good.I highly recommend it to players who enjoyed the earlier Dawn of War 2 games but for those who liked Dawn of War 1, don't expect the same building management.I still hope that Dawn of War 3 is being developed but the future looks dark.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I know a lot of people weren't huge fans of the way the hero mechanic was used in this series, but being a long time RTS gamer myself, I enjoyed a break from the norm. For the main campaign, there is no base building, only squad based unit management. It makes for a fun, fresh approach to a genre that hasn't seen a lot of revolutionary changes. Additionally, they've incorporated their own brand of survival mode called Last Stand, which is where I feel the entire DoW II series really shines. You choose and control a commander unit from one of the eight races, then match up with two other human players and play against wave after wave of increasingly difficult AI units. Each wave cleared provides experience, which is applied to your chosen commander and leads towards further war gear unlocks. Each level gained gives you access to more powerful abilities, attack types and survivability options.The game has it's issues in executing some of what people have come to expect from the older games in the DoW series, but if you approach Retribution without these preconceived notions, you will find a lot to enjoy.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												6/10 A very interesting, combat based RTS game with a pretty straightforward campaign. While up front this game seems like a well built game, it has some wierd balancing issues. Due to this, the selection for armies is pretty narrowed-down. The first example shows itself in the 'army painter', a utility for players to further customize their forces. It seems unassuming at first, but upon closer inspection, the issues begin to show themselves. When selecting colors, there are a few colors that end up giving boons in gameplay. To summarize, the only colors that make tactical sense is red, because it is more or less direct upgrade from all the other colors. Moving on to the army selection. This is where the balancing issues really start intervening with gameplay. The game includes many of the signature armies from Games-Workshop's tabletop game, most notably the Imperial Guard. Normally, each army has their own polarizations, such as one may be better at meelee combat, or one may be better at shooting. The problem here is, one of the armies, the Imperial Guard, is not polarized at all, and excells in all areas. This makes it the only real choice for players if they want to have a good experience. Some players actually try to cheat at the game in order to make armies like the Space Marines (the absolute worst faction) viable.Dealing with both of these issues, I found myself very limited in my choices when actually playing. The only combo I ended up using were red Imperial Guardsmen (Guardsmen are the all around best unit in the Imperial Guard). Buy at your discretion.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I wrote several reviews about this game, this is my final. This is not a strict strategy game, its a MOBA+strategy, a hybrid. Its good only for 2v2 and 3v3 and that's what most players of this game play. Its well suited for Faction war meaning all 3 heroes of the same faction together in the same team fighting all the 3 heroes of another faction. Playing the game like that its fun so i recommend real life friends to get it as this is how i started this game. Dont get the game if you are to play it solo you wont have fun. It would be great if its campaign had 4 player cooperate instead of 2 so that's a big deal negative, if there is a patch  that makes coop campaign for 4 players that would be great for each one controlling 1 hero. In general i only recommend to get this game if you have a real life premade team lets say or you plan to play it with online friends, its good for that.  DoW 2 Retribution is a poorly made mini CoH 1 and has nothing to do with Warhammer 40K. DoW 1 mods are WAY BETTER and are 40K SOLID. The graphics of this game are great and has a very good performance, if rating a game was to rate graphics it would get a 10/10. To a casual gamer i recommend this game, to someone who wants 40K no i dont. This is a review for both DoW 2 and DoW 2 Retribution. This game is over-simplified that's a major con of it, and its very small, its like mini mini mini...(n-times)...mini me.BUTThere is a mod called The Elite mod which added more units to the game and rebalanced it to a much better degree than retail and added in its strategy value, so if it is to play  DoW 2 get Elite mod, it has way more SOLID gameplay.Also another mod called Codex Edition, it is incomplete on 1 faction sadly, but as it is its still very good on its gameplay, it makes dow 2 very attractive but sadly it has some bugs.Personally i dont like DoW 2 for it could have been WAY BETTER but this is my personal opinion, many other pro gamers like it and find it real fun to play.Also there is another important feature of this game, the quotes, for every type of attack and direction of the attack a unit receives it quotes that attack so you know what it coming and from where and you can react fast and accurately, this is a great feature this game has. The game has very good graphic as well and it is beautiful. I dislike it cause of the gameplay meaning it COULD have been way better than it is, which is good still.********VERY IMPORTANT**********Base Turrets are the reason this game's multiplayer was bad. Base in multiplayer can heal and reinforce which is enough as troops can defend the stronghold, having base turrets made low mobile factions to have a HUGE disadvantage as they couldnt deal with retreat option against very mobile factions. Retreat option itself didnt break the game, base turrets did as it was impossible to attack a stronghold except very late game. If base turrets didnt exist(a player can make turrets i am talking about the default base turrets) this game's multiplayer would be MUCH better.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I think I played it enough to write a review.First of the all the game is amazing, there are 6 factions with which you can play with in the Single player and these factions are:The space marines, Chaos space marines, Imperial Guards, Orcs, Elder and the Tyranids.The campaign doesn't change between the races, but every time although you go through the same places and fight vs the same enemies it is still really fun and feels a little bit different!.Unlike in the previous games such as, Dawn of War: Soulstorm or Dawn of War 2 Chaos Rising, here you have 4 commanders which you control and you also construct an army but not a base, you get your units by capturing a beacon or barracks (depends on your race) and from there you can deply troops into the battlefield.The multiplayer is pretty active, a few cutom games here and there and it seems like people can't stop playing in the last stand! (The last stand is a game mod in which you group up with 2 more players and try to survive waves of enemies up to 20 waves)The game also has many dlc's many of them are skins for the multiplayer or some wargear for the single player, except for two DLC's which are the Tau commander and the Necron Overlord, these DLC's might be expensive, but if you really like the last stand which I mentioned above, you might want to consider buying it. The DLC will give you a new commander to play with in the last stand and he is damn powerful, but as powerful as he is, it doesn't mean he is more powerful than the other commanders, he has his pros and cons.Overall the game is amazing, the story is nice, really fun single player campaign and the multiplayer is active.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Alright. Let me start out with saying that in this game, contrary to Dawn of War +expansions (All respect to those as they're plain awesome), you actually get the feel of the Hero type you choose, and you get that feeling of being totally BEE AYE. You get to integrate a Hero, such as (And one of my personal favorites!) the Inquisitor, into a full on battle, and at last those herotypes get the venerable strength and versatility they deserve according to the lore.The gameplay itself, albeit lacking the whole base expansion thing as far as I've seen, as many other games got, this game makes up with it with on-the-go deployment whilst getting to fully fledge the units of yours into defensive postures much like the Company of Heroes style of games and you get to really unfold your tactical knowledge and strategic flair to their full extent, and put these to the test. So if you're a selfproclaimed master tactician, this is a game where you get to test it, without having humongous unconfined levels where the enemy can literally hide behind a bush and stay alive in that way. Not to mention, you get the opportunity of fielding your factions most devastative vehicles and infantry short of a full on exterminatus.The graphics are good though at first a tad confusing overlay wise, but aside from smaller nitpickings, I love the setting the game sets for each individual map and the level of details compromising the rather blocky HUD. In short: If you're in for a thrill and want to see some De&De up close, and get to feel like you're actually a commander in WH40K, this is the game for you.  Now have me excused while I go back to wreak more havoc on those xenos!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												10/10 One of my most played games recorded. The story does continue like it should with some epic graphic cutscenes that surely don't disappoint. The main reason I rate this so high and recommend is due to the multiplayer/Last StandMultiplayer- The multiplayer is very fun, having a few different modes that you may play with several tiers of units that you must micro manage to get that advantage over your opponents, strategy is critical to your victory. Sacrificing 50 points just to create your most powerful unit to then turn the tide of battle is one of those decisions you may have to make.Last Stand- Last stand is my favorite part of this game and is where most of my hours have gone. A strategic survival battle where you and 2 others last against many waves of enemies while using your unique skills which propose your role to the battle. Some are more AoE and taking out infantry where you may die fast, whereas some are bulky armored and focus more on the bigger tougher enemies on the battlefield.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Came from Dawn Of War, Stayed for Last Stand. I think, over 70% of the people who play this game, came for a better version of the original Dawn Of War, but got disappointed. Personally, I love base building, and to find out that it was removed was a real kick in the teeth. I've played multiplayer with a group of friends on both games, and they all agree that this seems watered down due to the absense of base building, but agree that the game feels much nicer. One other thing that bothered us was how easy the game seemed, even on harder difficulties. Yet, the original Dawn Of War is insane and very difficult. However, Last Stand is amazing. I play with the same group, and we really enjoy the game. Currently, our go to game to waste time. Really enjoyable and for that, I'll rate this positive. Don't get me wrong, multiplayer is still okay but, not as good as the original.I've played the campaign with a friend, and it's very good. We both enjoy the leveling system. I'm quite disappointed the fact you can't have 4 people, considering you control 4 heros and squads which can be real hard to micro manage each of their movements, especially since you have different roles like tanks and healers. Having 4 player campaign would be awesome. None the less I still enjoy the campaign.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I'm a little hesitant about recommending this, despite having enjoyed this game a lot.I can definitely see a few problems about this game.First one being that nobody plays the multiplayer anymore, so the best course of action is to also buy extra copies to give to friends for private multiplayer sessions.Second problem being that if you play this game before playing Dawn of War 1, DoW1's gameplay will be ruined for you.Aaaand the third problem: With THQ being dead, i'm concerned that a good chunk of that money will go to Games Workshop instead of Relic Entertainment.The positive aspects of the game would definitely have to be the combat system. While traditional RTS fans will dislike the lack of base building, i felt that the combat system was pretty well done, with shrubs and small pieces of rubble providing cover for infantry, vehicles taking extra damage from behind, and infantry suppression from weapon platforms such as the heavy bolter. In addition to the gameplay, the campaign is really about as good as it can get despite all the campaigns using the same map.Final verdict: While I believe that you should play this game if you have the slightest interest in Warhammer 40,000, wait for a bloody sale. Do you really want Games Workshop to earn 20 buxx for every copy of this game sold?

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Is it an ok game to pass a few hours on? well just look at the hours ive put in should tell you something.Having said that can I recommend it now? probably not.Whilst it's a fine game and deceptive simple looking it contains a heap of good strategy, some solid modes like the arena game, a good enough campaign though not as good as DOW 1's but it's the multiplayer that lets the game down in the end. When and if you do find a match you're going to run into the same issues Company of heroes 2 has in that your rarely going to get a game where not one person drops, robbing all players regardless of time played of their exp. Most do it out of spite, some just drop right at the start leaving you with a mess of a match as the ill equipped AI take over just goes around capping everything removing any fun or strategy from the game. Rarely have I enjoyed a good online match and 90% you will be met with nothing but frustration as players rage quit right at the end of the match to rob everyone of their rightful exp. The multiplayer is seriously flawed for this reason with no punishment system in place this will keep happening.For those reasons even though I had fun for a while I can't in all honesty recommend it to someone looking for a good experience either single player or multiplayer. Even for 40k fans there's games out there that do it far better at the end of the day.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This is a great action packed game with great graphics!  It has three game modes including single and co op campaign with 6 different races. The campaign can be set on easy, normal, hard and very hard.  The second game mode is multiplayer. You can also choose of 6 different races and their costume colors. You can do many different things on multiplayer, for e.g: 1v1, 2v2, 3v3 etc. But my personal favourite is Last Stand. You can choose out of 6 races (or 7 if you have dlc) and can the play on two different maps. You play with three different people and as you gain more experience you can make your character stronger by giving him armor, weapons, and traits and abilities. You should seriously think about getting this game!

												Retribution cannot continue the streak of marvel that Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising set up even although it is continuing their story. The gameplay is a mix of Dawn of War 2 as well as previous installments, meaning there's less hero composition and more standard units to recruit and replace. While ultimately being fun to play, the several campaigns all play out the same way and feel far inferior to the epicness of Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising.The Last Stand is by far the best version we've seen so far and for me personally, one of the truly redeeming features of Retribution, which, all in all, still is a great game, but not as great as the previous installments.A good pick for Dawn of War as well as Warhammer 40k fans, but probably not the best choice for people looking for a good RPG / Tactical Strategy game.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												If you are coming from the plethora of Dawn of War games before then you are well prepared for this installation of Dawn of War: Retribution. I won't lie, if you are here for the campaign, it is fairly dull. There are 6 factions to play. They include: Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, Tyranids, Imperial Guard, and Chaos Space Marines. The campaign takes place in a galaxy with numerous planets, representing your possible missions and various rewards. Your army consists of a couple heroes that carry over gamer after game and which you can level up and acquire new and better gear for. Playing through the campaign once is not bad. However, it is pretty much the same for each factions, meaning it will get repetetive after one or two walkthroughs. Don't want the campaign? How about skirmish against the AI to test your skills. It heavily revolves around controlling objectives to gain points and power to build your armies. The biggest downfall of the game was base building though. You start the game with one building. It's your command center that is responsible for spawning all your troops and researching all the tech. The goal of the match is to destroy the enemy HQ. It has a lot of HP and it takes more advanced troops to finally put it down. I have to say that I enjoy base building like Dawn of War Soulstorm had so this game was dissapointing. Multiplayer is largely as described above, just against players.What I really found fun in this game was Arena mode, also called The Last Stand. You can actually purchase it as a sepparate game and avoid paying the Full Price all together. The Last Stand mode lets you pick your general. They all start with level 1 and level up until 20, with each level granting them unique weapons, armors, and abilities. Your general is then taken to an arena (currently 2 variants) with 2 other players and left to survive 20 waves. Each wave throws various galactic abominations at you from all different factions and your only purpose is th "survive". So, can you?All in all. It's not a bad game. Graphics are alright and the campaign is good for 1-2 run throughs, the last stand mode is a lot of fun, and multiplayer is action packed. I would definitelly play this game at least once for the experience, but if you are the kind of person who expects major battles with big bases, this isn't the game for you. The population cap limits your army to a specific size and the lack of base building limits the ingenuity that some players might have brought to the battlefield.Good luck!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Epic Battles!This game is a RTS title that’s focussed on maintaining each and every unit you create.I love this game because each skirmish or multiplayer game is an epic adventure from start to finish.This game focuses allot more on the units rather than the base management. As soon as you start the game you are aggressively pushing forward and capturing resource points across the map. This style of play immediately puts you into the thick of it with the other player.  Which means fun right from the start!The campaign is very different from the skirmish part. It’s more like a dungeon crawl RPG with hero units you and a friend can control that go all over the map using special abilities from equipment you pick up or skills that you learn when you level up. It’s actually really fun.But this game shines on the multiplayer. The races are all very different and each race has 3 unique heroes than you take into battle. I can easily recommend this game to any RTS fan. There is allot more to this game than I explained in this short review. You’ll have a blast finding out all the different game modes.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												This reveiw is only about the multiplayer experience.Dawn of War 2:Retribution could have beenthe best rts game ever made. It offers 6 factions, each faction has 3 commanders and each commander can have 1 or 2 different playstyles, including wargear that you can buy for them to make them more adaptable to different situations, so the game has a lot of variety in playstyle.But the game still has some flaws, flaws that would have probably been fixed by THQ if they didnt shut down. For example the game can be pretty imbalanced in some matchups, for example chaos vs imperial guard, where the IG need to rush to tier 3 as fast as possible because every single tier 1 and tier 2 unit that the chaos forces ahve outclass the IG variant, the game is still fun though if you get a fair matchup, and i heard that the elite mod adressess a lot of balance issues and its pretty popular amongst the community, so if you dont like the base or get bored of it and want something else then you still have a good choice.Overall the game is still pretty good in its current state, its not a bad game, it can be a lot of fun at times, but it could be so much more, i wish relic would still bring new stuff to this game like they do with company of heroes, but if you are looking for a good strategy game in one of the most interesting settings in video game history, then this game might be what you need.

												I really do like this game. the last stand and multiplayer are very enjoyable indeed. Last Stand is where you choose a hero (ork, space marine, chaos, imperial guard or  tyranid) and you try to last as long as you can against hordes of enimies that get increasingly difficult. The multiplayer is where you fight against other people online. All fine and dandy... but then there's the campaign. In the campaign you choose from any of the five races (the same ones from the Last Stand) and work your way through a story (obviously) and you give your heroes better armour, weapons etc. The only problem is all of the campaigns are pretty much the same except for dialogue, troops and the race that you are. Though the campaign is kind of fun when you play with a friend.So it's a pretty good game over all and I enjoy it. But if you're looking for replayability on a campaign and that's all you want give it a miss. But if you don't care about that play it for multiplayer and Last Stand because they are really fun!

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												This reveiw is only about the multiplayer experience.Dawn of War 2:Retribution could have beenthe best rts game ever made. It offers 6 factions, each faction has 3 commanders and each commander can have 1 or 2 different playstyles, including wargear that you can buy for them to make them more adaptable to different situations, so the game has a lot of variety in playstyle.But the game still has some flaws, flaws that would have probably been fixed by THQ if they didnt shut down. For example the game can be pretty imbalanced in some matchups, for example chaos vs imperial guard, where the IG need to rush to tier 3 as fast as possible because every single tier 1 and tier 2 unit that the chaos forces ahve outclass the IG variant, the game is still fun though if you get a fair matchup, and i heard that the elite mod adressess a lot of balance issues and its pretty popular amongst the community, so if you dont like the base or get bored of it and want something else then you still have a good choice.Overall the game is still pretty good in its current state, its not a bad game, it can be a lot of fun at times, but it could be so much more, i wish relic would still bring new stuff to this game like they do with company of heroes, but if you are looking for a good strategy game in one of the most interesting settings in video game history, then this game might be what you need.
