content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Two player coop with friend controlling Space Marines, Chaos SM, Eldar, Tyranids, Orks and Imperial Guard. Each has their own unique skills and character progression. This plays similarly to Company of Heroes.The stories for each race are sadly almost identical but I have come to terms with this because you get awesome coop and multiplayer and The Last Stand (TLS) which is a COBA (Co-Operative Battle Arena) where you take 3 people into a small arena with waves of enemies to beat your way through. There are 2 arena levels although maybe someday people will mod new ones in or mod new characters in. There are a few mods for this game and they seem to have a fairly stable following and as a whole the online prescence is stable and doesnt seem to be going anywhere.The Last Stand is by far my fave thing about this game. They even added a Necron Lord and a Tau Crisis Suit to play with, again sadly this is DLC but its one fo the few I just bit down and took it in the wallet. For a longtime TT fan, this game is gravy!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												There are  a few things that run wrong with this game. However, it just might be for me and no one else. This game is like lets make Dow 1 & 2 have a baby and call it Retribution. A lot of the things that I didn't like about the first game was the fact that it was just focused on Bloodravens and a handful of Space Marines. However, this game has 5 different factions to it. I LOVE that it is all optional. Unless your are trying to get that 100%. Then it is going to take some time. I think it is interesting that they still focused the game on a handful of people but they made it into different factions. Here is the thing, you can kind of play it like it was DoW 1 because you don't have to take anybody except the commander and then you are able to have more people in the game. The treasure chests are now there for resources instead of helpful items. In fact, the helpful items are not exactly gone but they are now abilities. Which is something that I love. I have to say that I am still more of a fan of the first game. However, Retribution is a damn fine game The abilities that you choose for your team is amazing. You don't even have to really upgrade anyone. That option is up to you. I don't really play a lot of games online. So I can't comment on the online play. The things that I didn't like about this game that I think it  may or may not be just me. Is that sometimes you click on an area they just don't go to it or even acknowledge it. I've had this weird skipping across the game sometimes but then when I loaded back it. It worked fine. I another thing is that I feel because there was so many options for factions, that the storlyine to all of them are short. With it's negatives, I still think this is a really good game. I like that they incorperate both the good from the earlier games. I like that there are more factions now. The skill system I think is way better in this than in DoW 2. I highly recommend playing this games.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												I like this game. A lot. I like the theme/setting of the game. This is particularly ironic because, as a player of tabletop wargames, I do not like the Warhammer 40k tabletop setting at all. But in this video game, the factions and their units look and play great.I've touched the campaign and looked at last stand, but I really spent my time in this game doing multiplayer (1v1, 2v2, 3v3, TFFA, and, always to my everlasting displeasure, annihilation).I like how this game is not about base-building and sending unit after unit off to die on the battlefield. It's about keeping units, and improving units. Because of the time you spend with your guys, this game is about loving your units. It's great to see that Guardian squad that I started the match with 18 minutes later, rolling with the support of a Warlock, embolded,  and dropping effective grenades in the late game. Or that Banshee squad who even after seeing some extremely close, close calls thoughout the match and coming within just a few hit points of an untimely death, regrouped and putting the hurts on a dreadnought in the late game. But not everyone can survive, and when you lose a unit the pain is real! You find yourself giving micro-eulogies to your fallen squads, thanking them for thier contribution to the effort and reminding them that it was, hopefully, not in vain.This is the aspect of the game that I like the most. But there are other cool things. I like that there are asymetrical maps (just like on my tabletop). I like how the hero characters (I've only play Eldar>Warlock) work in the game's mechanics. I like the suppression weapon platforms and how they work with arcs and set-up/break-down timers.I really like the timing of the game. I like how you have time to flank a turtling Techmarine who hides behind his too-many-turrets. Or how you can chose to just ignore his turret spam until you get to Tech level II and address it then. There's plenty of other places to attack. (Oh, how many times have I seen poor players, including my noob-self, continuing to attempt to push into turrets and pay the full cost for the choice when it could have addressed later?)Anyway. those are somethings I like about this game. I guess I paid $60 for this game when it came out and I've played for over 1500 hours, so that's less than 4 cents per hour. You can't beat that with a D-Cannon.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Warhammer 40k DoW II is a moba like twist on the beloved origonal DoW franchise, for some it will be a welcome change, for others a turning point to other games.As an fan of the old DoW game / expansions i found that this was a wierd yet intriguing change for me, the game focuses less on base building (all you can build is generators and you can upgrade your main base, thats it) and focuses more on the constant exchanging of forces and holding capture points.For people who are used to the general combat of games like Star Craft II this will be similar to how you DoW II runs with no base building and a focus on controlling points. the big focus for this game is control and managing your units effectivly. this can be appealing to some and off putting for others this expansion / all in one game is better than DoW II itself and id say just get this as it adds more units and another storyline (which isnt amazing but works)so in general i would say if you want the old DoW game then give this a skip, but if you want a Warhammer 40k game similar to Star Craft II then id say go for itDisclaimer**i have played Star Craft II, im no pro or anything and i dont know 100% what im talking about so this is just a general view i can give and comparision from to 80+ hours ive played**

												I only have The Last Stand DLC which is a multiplayer coop survival mode and is sold like a separate game. I like this game because of visuals and Warhammer assets. There are only 2 maps for this mode and 20 waves on each map. You'll need to play this maps over and over to get enough XP and be able to finish all 20 waves. At first I thought that it is lame, but the game is a pleasure to play and you enjoy to gain this XP and new weapons. You can also get a dose of adrenaline when playing on the last waves. Co-op is not enforced(I mean that everybody plays mostly solo), but if you get to agree with other players you can have even more fun using some tactics(happens rarely).

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												The missions seemed bland and formulaic - Drop in, go somewhere, shoot things along the way, fight a boss once you reach the end. Occasionally this is broken up by the mission prodding you along (the infamous BEHNBLADE), or having to deal with fortified strongpoints.The gameplay itself actually seemed weaker than the previous DoW II titles - While it's still a very unit-centric squad-based RTT, there's a lot more units available to you and on the field in general, each with their own properties. Normally I wouldn't complain about having a lot to keep track of, but micro-heavy gameplay like slotting your infantry into good cover and placing/orienting heavy weapons squads works best when you're dealing with smaller forces rather than larger ones. This is especially amplified by the general trend towards smaller engagements; Fairly frequently, I'd be cramming 40 guardsmen into a space meant for a dozen Space Marines.Basic encounters tended to feel chaotic, but not urgent - Lots to keep track of, but not a whole lot on the line.Boss fights rapidly became repetitive. The nature of them, one at the end of every level, plus the limited unit selection brought about by 40k armies meant that, fairly often, I'd be fighting yet *another* Hive Tyrant, except this time in a jungle-themed arena rather than a gothic cathedral-themed one.Honestly, I think Chaos Rising is a lot stronger than Retribution, simply because it's closer to the overall design of the series. Retribution has a lot more units on the field to play around with, but Dawn of War 2 isn't a game that's designed for that and it shows.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Dawn Of War II Retribution Takes place in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, a milky way galaxy filled with xenos, daemons and super soldiers called Space Marines. It has a campaign for all 6 playable races the Eldar, Chaos Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Space Marines, Tyranids, and Orks. It has a 3 player co op survival mode called The Last Stand, which has 2 different maps to play on. The Multiplayer is great you can have up to 3 Versus 3 Player versus Player or with ai. There is also an army painter for you to make your own army names and color schemes. My personal rating of this game is a 9 out of 10 because a few things seem overly powerful, but other than that this game is very balanced. So Good luck, Have fun, and get out there and PURGE FOR THE EMPORER!!!!

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Dawn Of War II Retribution Takes place in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, a milky way galaxy filled with xenos, daemons and super soldiers called Space Marines. It has a campaign for all 6 playable races the Eldar, Chaos Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Space Marines, Tyranids, and Orks. It has a 3 player co op survival mode called The Last Stand, which has 2 different maps to play on. The Multiplayer is great you can have up to 3 Versus 3 Player versus Player or with ai. There is also an army painter for you to make your own army names and color schemes. My personal rating of this game is a 9 out of 10 because a few things seem overly powerful, but other than that this game is very balanced. So Good luck, Have fun, and get out there and PURGE FOR THE EMPORER!!!!

Posted: July 31, 2011
												Dawn of War II has a really interesting universe. The campaign in this game clearly shows love for the Space Marine faction, every other campaign seems tacked on and unimportant. The graphics are good, as well as the sound design. The Strategy elements are well done. It's the same engine as Company of Heroes, so it basically plays the same as that game, however the engine feels a little bit better in this type of universe. The game is definitely geared towards multiplayer, but the its either a hit or miss. The mechanics of the game are easily fustrating in a game of poor connections and none of the strategic elements are clear enough to know what's what. Counters are hard to learn on your own, as well as build orders and proper micro's. There are a good community of players geared toward helping players imrpove their game, but if you not totally invested into the game's stats and numbers for every unit prepared to get scraped over and over again because the player base is 75% veteran.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												Is this a good game? It is... It's fun, and fast paced... But I feel like it didn't capture the feel of the original dawn of war, due to the fact that they COMPLETELY take away the base building, which is something in RTS's I enjoy. However, I'm going to base this review in the style I did for the first Dawn of War, Speaking from a die hard Warhammer fan.Let's go over the positives of this game...-The action and pathing are improved, You are stuck right into it. and the fights are fun to watch.-The Voice acting in this game, is superb. And Very well done.-The campaign is very well made, However, this also contains a flaw, which I'll go over.-Multiplayer play is quite well, and still has multple game types, like the first Dawn of war game.-Each unit has to be treated like the table top counter part, such as, some are expendable, but if you keep losing too much, you will lose. Which has an immersion factor for me.-The soundtrack... Oh My God... The soundtrack for this game, is probably one of the best I've heard... -The developers added attention to detail, and added unit cries and announcer cries that differ depending on what race you are going against. for example, If you play orks, and then order an attack on an eldar, they might say something like "Eldar ar da squishiest.." Capturing the humor and immersion of the Warhammer universe.-To make the game more strategic, you have a small population, So choosing your units contains strategy to it.-The last stand mode is really fun, and it's a great idea. Holding off hordes of enemies with other players controlling your character is quite immersive.That's the positive aspects of this game... now for the negative.-The campaign is only fun once. As you get through playing with your race, you'll notice it's the exact same missions, but just with different races, which hugely downs the fun factor to it. Which leaves multiplayer and skirmish the only thing that maybe can bring you back.-The no base building is quite disapointing... Many RTS fans, such as myself, loved base building, due to it allowing you to manage and macro, while this game just focuses on micro.-The races seem more similar this time around... I don't know why, but it feels like they share some of the same strategies, Which doesn't help this game much for bringing you back, and keeping you in. Of course, this is my opinion, comparing it to the original, which felt like you are playing a different race. Don't get me wrong, there are differences, just not as much as I'd like. More like a peeve I suppose, so if you feel they are different, ignore this.-Giving the small population, Which is also a good thing, but it has a flaw for me, I like commanding big armies, Having a swarm of tyranids, or a horde of orks is probably the best feeling for me, but this game downs the population, which I can understand.Basically, this game can be fun, but it lacks compared to the others imo... I'd say only try it if you are a die hard warhammer fan. But this is my opinion, yours may differ. If you want to get into the universe of Warhammer 40k, try the first Dawn of war instead.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												A wonderful RTS which focuses on managing fewer units and forgoes base building and large scale macromanagement. Oozes 40k charm with each unit, with multiplayer and singleplayer offering both a quality experiance and with massive replayability.Buy it if you have any interest in warhammer 40k, buy it if you like RTS or Company of Heroes, buy it because decent Warhammer games need your cashbucks to thrive.If you already own this game play it more, the fantastic Elite mod offers continual support and its sheer accessibility means you can get good games going very quickly. The wall of inaccessability which hobbles most RTS is absent here, allowing games against even experianced players to go either way with the right choices - rather than build orders and meta gaming dictating the outcome before the game even begins.Probably the best Warhammer game out there, and it deserves your attention.

												Dawn of War II: Retribution is a good game to pick up. Especially if you are a huge 40k buff like myself. Each race feels unique and powerful. (Sometimes overpowered. Looking at you Tyranids.) Definitely deserves a look if you like RTS games and a must buy if on sale.

Posted: March 15, 2011
												The Emperor demands that you acquire this title and proceed to aid your brothers in cooperative skirmishes and campaigns against the heresy of Chaos. And the WAAAAAAAAAAAAGH likes your hat by the way.Now then. The singleplayer campaign can be played with all the 6 races - Space Marines, Chaos Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, Tyranid and Imperial Guard. The maps are the same, almost completely. But the story and how it branches out are not the same, and seeing how every race plays differently it adds a lot of replayabillity. Did I mention all the campaigns are co-op? Oh. Well, I did now. Besides this, you get to play an RTS which does not focus on the boring aspect - wasting 5-15 minutes building a base. In Skirmishes, you are given a single building - A barracks of sorts. This is your only building, in which you produce your units. You capture and hold the points around the map to get requisition (money) and power (power), which adds another strategic element. I like. Go git.

Posted: April 26, 2015
												This game is for your little strategic man/woman inside you.You can play with the most popular races, (still needs some races like necrons *COF* *COF*) Eldar, Space marines, the mighty imperial guard, the Chaos forces, and the ork WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHG, every race has special units, like the Avatar of Khaine of the Eldar, or the mighty Wartruck (da best thing EVAH ;P) of the Orks. When you start playing the campaing you realise something is happening, a big PLOT cooking inside. And it's AWESOME.The multiplayer is fun but you realise when you are fighting against a player who played more than you in multiplayer when  he is alredy in front of your base and conquering all the points, but still, you can learn how to battle against em, after a couple of matches you will understand the tactics they use. And remember, allways take cover, cover is IMBA. :PI really love this game, but i miss the building part from Dawn of War vanilla. 9/10

Posted: July 8, 2015

Posted: October 14, 2011
												WoooooooootSo I've decided to make this a proper review.Let's get straight to the point. DoW2, much like it's predecessor, is a RTS set in the grimdark world of Warhammer 40,000. Unlike its predecessor however, your battles are on a far smaller scale. No longer do you have a huge squad of 9 marines per squad for example. Nor can you build more than one Land Raider. Instead squad sizes are far smaller(unless you're 'nids or orks in which case numbers wins the day), and focused more on flanking, tactics, special abilities and the like. In my opinion this actually makes the game more enjoyable for me. DoW1 felt too much like any stereotypical RTS wearing a 40k skin. DoW2 feels unique. The campaign is basically an adventure, with a neat story, neat gear and the like. Done with campaign and bored of it? RTS battles await. Don't want to play it as a RTS? Last Stand. For a game that is this old now, there's plenty to see and do. If you're a 40k fan, then every now and then it's great to get your 40k kicks in.DoW2 Retribution is perhaps the last great 40k game. None of those released after it so far has been anywhere as epic a journey. Until Sega decides to make a DoW3, this game above all else, is probably THE 40k PC game I'd choose if I had to pick one to play for the rest of my life.And I guess it'd be remiss not to mention that I'm massively into 40k today only because of this game.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												Dawn of War II: Retribution is a superbly made Real-Time Strategy game. Each player has a HQ from which they build units. Unlike a lot of strategy games, Retribution does not require the player to build structures to train units and gather resources. Rather, you start the game off with your choice of 1 of 3 of your chosen factions hero, as well as the basic infantry type of your faction. Then, to gather resources you command your units to capture Requisition (the main resource used for everything) and Power (a secondary resource for purchasing more advanced units and upgrading your units and their tech as well as researching the next tier) points. For each point you capture, the amount of Requistion/Power you earn per second increases. The only disappointment i have with all of the Dawn of War games is the very limited unit cap of 100.Don't let that stop you from getting this amazing game, perfect for new players and RTS veterans!Jester's Rating: 8.5/10

Posted: September 10, 2015
												TLDR – Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a standalone Real Time Strategy game following the events of Warhammer 40k Dawn of War 2 and its DLC Chaos Rising.  This time around you actually get to manage some resources and build a few units instead of just commanding a team of heroes.I didn’t play Chaos Rising, and a bunch of stuff apparently happened in the story so I wasn’t sure of the timeline on starting Retribution (the stories are pretty much completely unrelated). Fortunately, the plot is cohesive and you should be able to follow it if you have basic knowledge of the Warhammer 40k universe. Note that despite the fact that there are 6 different races to play in Retribution, they all have pretty much the same story. Space Marine, Chaos Space Marine, Eldar, Ork, Tyranid, and Imperial Guard all play the same series of missions just with slight changes to the narration. Basically, no matter which team you’re on, you need to stop a bad guy from ascending to demon form before an Imperial extermination force wipes out the entire star sector. If you’ve played Real Time Strategy Games like Starcraft, Warcraft, or Command & Conquer, you should be able to pick up Retribution’s gameplay almost immediately. But instead of building a base and harvesting resources, you start each level with hero units and need to work your way across the map while claiming resource “nodes” and command points. Do you remember the “commando” missions from Starcraft where you need to get your hero through the level relying on special powers while occasionally having backup appear? Well the whole game of Retribution is like that. The enemy is already entrenched in each level, and each of your hero units has special abilities gained through level ups and / or special items (war gear). The war gear is randomly dropped during gameplay and equipped between missions. So beating the game is mostly about managing your energy (mana) for using special powers and not biting off more than you can chew at once.The game has a cover system where if you move near certain items on the map like buildings or busted up walls, your units will attempt to hide behind them for a defense bonus, but honestly with so many special powers flying around, the cover isn’t as important as blasting the enemy before he blasts you. Make sure you diversify the equipment and special powers of your team and take your time with each level. You will find the game is not very difficult, especially if you’re playing as the Tyranid race. The Tyranids seem to be unique in that you only get one hero in the campaign (but that hero is seriously badass). Along with your hero units, you have the opportunity to requisition additional units at command points throughout each level. These units are obviously much weaker than your heroes but you can build up a nice army and flank enemy positions. The army will never be too big due to the population cap, but it does make finishing each level easier.Pros:+Fun game and not very punishing for casual gamers.  It’s pretty hard to actually lose, I don’t think I failed even one level. It just takes patience for your energy to recharge before you assault fortified enemy positions. +There is some variety in gameplay. Like the original Dawn of War 2, your units mostly have both melee and ranged attacks and you can gear up your units with particular equipment to enhance your play style. With 6 different playable races you shouldn’t be surprised to find that you’re occasionally fighting each of the six races throughout your campaign.+There are still people playing the game online if multiplayer is what you’re into. When I played there were usually about 300 other players though I didn’t really interact with them. I did try the Last Stand gameplay mode which is a 3 person co-op vs waves of enemies (took about 2-3 minutes to set up each match). I didn’t get very far but it seems to be the kind of game mode where you keep playing to level up, and hence get further and further along. Yes, there is also a co-op campaign mode.Cons:-Like the original Dawn of War 2, there are a ton of Steam achievements that seem tied to multiplayer. If you’re mostly into single player story campaigns like me, you’ll beat the game with less than 20% achievements and bring down your overall stats :(-As I mentioned before, all the races essentially have the same campaign. This makes the game surprisingly short and you can be done with it in about 2 days. No point in continuously replaying the same missions unless you’re grinding for achievements.Overall the game is fun if you’re into real time strategy or the Warhammer universe. If you have a friend to play co-op or Last Stand mode with, even better. Just note that getting far in Last Stand will require a significant time investment. There’s not much luck and skill involved until higher waves, and to get there you need to be high level.  And again, if you’re playing the single player campaign as Tyranid, play it in Hard or Very Hard difficulty mode unless it’s your very first time playing a real time strategy game. They’re just too strong for normal difficulty if you focus on ranged warriors.

Posted: July 6, 2011
												Dawn of War II? Moar like Dawn of War II, III and IV, amirite? Okay, it's not that huge, but it can make for really fun times, and really does happen to be more like three games than just one.  You've got the campaigns which play out as an action RPG. In Vanilla and Chaos Rising, you follow the exploits of a group of Blood Raven Space Marines, super soldiers out to save the day and stuffs. Retribution here lets you pick any of the factions available in the game for your campaign. The single-player/co-op is a lot like a Dungeon Siege style of RPG, where you get to handle squad leaders with ability points and items as you level up. Multiplayer is a fast paced RTS, with matches that last around 30 minutes and jump into the thick of it, without having to worry about base building at all. Lastly, The Last Stand. It's a game on its own. Play as heroes, and team up with others to survive waves of mooks. It's as fun as it is nightmarishly addicting. So yup. That's all, folks!

Posted: October 15, 2011
												9/10Retribution is the second and last expansion pack of Dawn of War II, and between the three games which compose the II storyline, Retribution is most certainly my favorite. It possesses all the content of the previous two games, updated with the inclusion of the Imperial Guard faction alongside new units for every race. These include superheavy units for each race, and now your Space Marines, Orks and Tyranids will have something to fight those pesky Avatars of Khaine and Great Unclean Ones with the addition of Land Raiders, Ork Battlewagons, the Swarmlord himself and the Imperial Guard's newly arrived Baneblade.Retribution has its own campaign which serves as a conclusion for the storyline of not only Dawn of War II and Chaos Rising, but also for Dawn of War I and its own expansion packs. All that has happened in the games' storyline has led up to this game, and you have the opportunity to play as any of the races in the campaign. While the campaign is repetitive (all races share the same missions and overall story), it is nonetheless enjoyable to go around defeating armies of daemons with irish Ork space pirate captains.Retribution also wins because it has the best voice acting. Everyone has a british accent. EVERYONE.IN THE GRIM DARKNESS OF THE FUTURE, EVERYONE IS BRITISH.AND I LOVE IT.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												The new (now old) DoW 2 : Retribution is a very beautiful looking game. Graphics are very good, gameplay is somewhere in between good and bad. When comes to Single Player/Campaign game is actually really good, it's a mix of RPG and strategy. You can build and customize your heros and armies and play in interesting linear campaign missions. Also a good thing to say, is that you can experience same story from angle of total 6 races, bad side is that all 6 races have same identical missions, only different is final goal. So once you complete campaign with one race, you have seen it all. But DoW 2 and expanision shine in Campaign gameplay but are total let down when comest to multiplayer and skirmish against AI.As an old player of DoW: Soulstorm, multiplayer game experience was mix of huge armies and building a bases all over the map. DoW2 and this Retributin expansion offers you a small scale battles (in true meaning of word skirmishes ). You will lead maybe a 4 or 5 units max at the time, there is no base building, every unit comes from one building, which means you can't build two different units at the same time, which slows gamelplay drastically. Resaurces are scarce.Pros:CampaignGraphicsSingle Player gameplayCons:No base buildingTraining one unit at the timeScarce resourcesSmall battlesTraining both vehicles and units of all types from one single building.My Recommendation:Buy it for campaign and good looks, but for real and better 40k experience buy DoW:Soulstorm or Dark Crusade.So first DoW + expansions for MultiPlayer and DoW2 + expansions for SinglePlayer (Campaign)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Warhammer 40, 000: Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a completely different game from the other earlier 40k RTS's. This one focuses more on squad combat and strategy, rather than whoever gets the biggest army (maybe) or whoever rushes first. There is no more base building, which is kind of a disappointment but not a huge deal breaker. There is a single campaign that you can go through with the six races (Eldar, Tyranid, Space Marine, Imperial Guard, Orks, and Chaos). The campaign is the same for every race with minor story variations. The part about it that makes me the most sad is that they removed the Necrons and the Tau as if they never existed. Again, not a huge deal breaker, but still. You can get the Shas'O Commander and Necron Overlord in The Last Stand gametype as DLC (a little overpriced if you ask me), but that's the extent of it. The Last Stand is basically a horde mode consisting of you and two others. I am not kidding when I say it is pretty damn hard and evidently takes some getting used to. The community seems nice enough as well, though it's better to play with friends.This is a great game with improved graphics, physics, and well, it's Warhammer 40k. What more could you ask for?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												The surviving RTS game in this world, and it still stands out as a great game. Pros:+ Great variety of units+ Races are interesting and beautifully crafted (Tyranids, holy mother of god, these reminds me of Godzilla)+ In-Depth strategy+ The leveling system of units, though some don't like it, I say it is a good system to employ so that players don't just command his/her units aimlessly.+ Last Stand is a great alternative game mode. It reminds me of RPG games, with strategy sprinkle onto it. (E.g. Demigod)++ No other game allows you customize your units' color.Cons- Campaign. It reminds me of CnC4, a bit short, and a bit unnecessary. Wish it was the DOW I Dark Crusade's style of campaign.- Sometimes, units will not activate their skills. (Hive Tyrant's Bio Plasma, for example. He will stand there even though you issued the command.)- Seemed that spamming range units is better than melee units. Melee units are a bit underpowered in this game in my opinion.Overall, it's a great game. I hope that the RTS genre will survive in this MMORPG-ruled universe.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Dawn of War 2 and DoW2: Chaos Rising made a vast departue from the original Dawn of War games, going from a grand scale RTS similar to Command and Conquer to a squad-focused action-strategy game (for want of a better term). Retribution tries to marry the two, giving you a four-man team of hero units to work with and providing the option to exchange them for less-complicated but weaker elite squads before deployment or even calling in larger forces on the field (back to the DoW classic formula, albeit with perhaps fewer unit choices, particularly in the vehicular department).But honestly, the hero units (and/or their elite squad replacements) are usually enough to complete most missions by themselves. Where DoW was like the equivalent of a standard game of tabletop Warhammer 40K, DoW2: Retribution is more like playing a game of Kill Team. In fact, if you're planning to buy the Kill Team game on Steam, don't bother; just buy this instead.Also, the Last Stand multiplayer mode is super-fun. It's probably dead nowadays, but if you can get into an active server or have a few friends with the game, give it a go!9/10 it okay, not subtle or nuanced but it okay

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Retribution follows up the story events of Chaos Rising, and then allows you to play a number of different single-player campaigns as each of the different playable races. Unlike in Winter Assault however, the campaigns here are... pretty much the same thing everytime without any real difference between the races. This is one of those games where multiplayer was the chief focus, and the "Last Stand" Mode actually can be kinda fun if you can manage to get some people together who know what they are doing.As for me, however, it's just one more grindy multiplayer experience vying for my attention... and I have WAY too many of those as is.I'll give this a "yes" because it does not do anything wrong per se, but this game is pretty much for Warhammer 40k fans only, as far as I am concerned.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Chaos Rising, in my opinion, was a full fledged expansion. Completely worth full price because it extended the story and introduced a corruption mechanic to the campaign.  I really can't comment on online PVP because I only ever dabbled in Last Stand (Which is an excellent addition to the game, I'd like to see more PVE like it in the franchise.)Retribution, while it allowed me to finally sucker punch the system with Eliphas, felt like half a game when it came to the story.  They did their best to allow every faction to have their spotlight, but in trying to please everyone sort of left the experience feeling a bit lackluster, in hindsight.  At least incomparison to the previous two.This isn't unique to retribution, it occurs in all the DoWII titles I own: It does have some running problems on my junker of a laptop; dropping to a single frame per second during loading sequences.  It just really hates transitioning back to the star map after a mission. I still really enjoy the game and play through all three once a year or so.  Best snagged when the whole bundle is on special.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Warhammer 40, 000: Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a completely different game from the other earlier 40k RTS's. This one focuses more on squad combat and strategy, rather than whoever gets the biggest army (maybe) or whoever rushes first. There is no more base building, which is kind of a disappointment but not a huge deal breaker. There is a single campaign that you can go through with the six races (Eldar, Tyranid, Space Marine, Imperial Guard, Orks, and Chaos). The campaign is the same for every race with minor story variations. The part about it that makes me the most sad is that they removed the Necrons and the Tau as if they never existed. Again, not a huge deal breaker, but still. You can get the Shas'O Commander and Necron Overlord in The Last Stand gametype as DLC (a little overpriced if you ask me), but that's the extent of it. The Last Stand is basically a horde mode consisting of you and two others. I am not kidding when I say it is pretty damn hard and evidently takes some getting used to. The community seems nice enough as well, though it's better to play with friends.This is a great game with improved graphics, physics, and well, it's Warhammer 40k. What more could you ask for?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												The surviving RTS game in this world, and it still stands out as a great game. Pros:+ Great variety of units+ Races are interesting and beautifully crafted (Tyranids, holy mother of god, these reminds me of Godzilla)+ In-Depth strategy+ The leveling system of units, though some don't like it, I say it is a good system to employ so that players don't just command his/her units aimlessly.+ Last Stand is a great alternative game mode. It reminds me of RPG games, with strategy sprinkle onto it. (E.g. Demigod)++ No other game allows you customize your units' color.Cons- Campaign. It reminds me of CnC4, a bit short, and a bit unnecessary. Wish it was the DOW I Dark Crusade's style of campaign.- Sometimes, units will not activate their skills. (Hive Tyrant's Bio Plasma, for example. He will stand there even though you issued the command.)- Seemed that spamming range units is better than melee units. Melee units are a bit underpowered in this game in my opinion.Overall, it's a great game. I hope that the RTS genre will survive in this MMORPG-ruled universe.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												Let me start with this, I love both Dawn of War and Dawn of War II and all of their expansions.One is a RTS and the other one, I would consider it as a real-time tactics game.I love both, It's different, it sure would have been better to have two gamemodes (one that would be the classic from the first one and the other one would be what we got in the second game).That would have made it far better but that is not my biggest complain about this game.I'll start with its flaws.It's missing factions the previous game (its expansions) has, why can't we get them in this game? I find it very stupid because it's always like that in the modern gaming industry.I'll explain it to you in a simple manner that everyone should be able to understand.Keep in mind that this will be an example that doesn't directly apply to Dawn of War II.But it sure is a fact for many games.First game - 1996 - 6 factionsFirst expansion for the first game - 1997 - +2 factions, campaign and all the other great stuff.Second expansion for the first game - 1998 - +2 factions, campaign and all the other great stuff.Third expansion for the first game - 2000 - + 2 factions, graphics remastered, audio remastered, new content and other great stuff.Second game - 2008 - 2 factionsFirst expansion for the second game - 2008/2009 +2 factions (that were already in the base game of the orignal game without expansions) plus few content.Second expansion for the second game - 2009/2010 + 2 factions, skins and things people should not care about.Tell me, which one is worth more?Of course, Dawn of War II isn't as worse, I was especially thinking about Blood Bowl to Blood Bowl 2.The expansions of Dawn of War II are good, and they're expansions, unlike most of nowadays games which are just crappy "DLCs" (generally cut content before release) but they're still missing factions that they already invented.Release it as an expansion at worse, make it worth with a campaign, a few new maps and interesting content.That would be that.I hate the fact that we can't play as the Necro, the Tau, the Sisters of Battle nor as the Dark Eldar in this game.The thing to do would have been to released them all right from its the game release and to release other/new factions with the expansions, that's how it works, that's how it should works, that's how we advance.I could name a lot of great old games who do that and it works pretty well and most of them aren't so known because they are not mainstream/triple A made games.But they're even better because they have variety, lot of variety, and the gameplayer and stuff gets better after each release.So a developer such as Relic Entertainment have no excuses, I repeat, NO excuses! at all.It pains me to see where the gaming industry is going.Don't get me wrong, I love this game and that is why I leave my review positive.There is much, much worse, and it's everywhere.But still, this game could have been so much more.And it should have.9/10 for the game itself.4/10 for the fact that it's missing so many things.I sincerely hope that it will change for the best soon but I doubt it.Anyway, great game itself despise missing a few factions and content/stuff.I would suggest it if you're into the Warhammer universe and if you love real time tactical games.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												This is an insult to the players of the previous games in the series. I don't mind the change to the format of the single player campaign, but the atrocious lack of quality is unexpected given how much thought and time was put into the first two campaigns. -The maps are almost all long snaking paths where you just roll through watching stuff die. There's very little in the way of tactics or strategy, even on hard difficulty. -The hero/unit upgrades were not well thought out. It's very easy to trivialize the campaign, in terms of difficulty, by stacking upgrades on certain well rounded units and then just attack-moving through the entire level. There's no challenge, it's not interesting aside from just watching a bunch of explosions go off.-There is not much detail or attention given to quality story development compared to the previous installments, with poor or non-existent justification for the missions you undertake, and very little in terms of voice over work.-There is little thought or time given to customizing the campaign for each race. They all play out exactly the same, with minor changes in dialogue being all you usually get (if even that), only occasionally having a different in-game cutscene at the start of the level. -There's no real replay value considering that there's no real decision making involved in the missions. The only replay value would be in choosing different upgrade paths for units, but the campaign is too easy so there's no incentive to try different strategies. -There are many bugs and evidence of lack of playtesting. It feels like they put no love or care into this, rushing it out on bare minimal resources. Units get stuck on terrain. Building lots of units in the campaign bugs out their pathfinding, causing them to get stuck. There is even a part where as imperial guard the commander calls for artillery fire but an orbital strike comes in instead (which is what happens when you play as space marines), showing that they intended to do something unique for the IG campaign but ultimately did not bother to animate it in.Overall it's a disgrace of a campaign for Relic's usual quality, and an insult to the customer that they would expect this to be a good value considering what they are capable of delivering. It feels like they are just trying to quickly tie up the DOW2 storyline because they don't have the resources to do a proper single player campaign.However, the one saving point of this expansion is that it gives you access to the Imperial Guard in multiplayer - Which is done to a very high standard of quality in terms of it's design and artwork, on par with the races before it. They are quite fun to play, having a different style based around cover for infantry, defensive structures, and vehicle support.Unfortunatley for Imperial Guard multiplayer, they also miss the mark on a few big issues:1. Lack of numbers. IG is known for numbers, but you never have the population capacity to utilize large numbers of guardsmen at once. The only way they simulate this is by making guardsmen very cheap and quick to re-enforce compared with other races.2. Lack of on-map artillery support. This is a huge part of IG military doctrine, so the lack of a basalisk on the map really kills a lot of the potential fun you could have holding the line behind entrenchments while you lay down fire support. The off-map artillery options are a poor substitute for the on-map artillery of DOW1, and the on-map manticore (rocket based artillery) is not very effective or satisifying to use - It doesn't fill the role of sustained fire support; because of it's single volley and long cooldown. Although it is at least some form of artillery which has it's uses, it's a let down compared to how IG play in DOW1. And the low population cap makes it difficult sometimes to use a proper mix of combined arms, because you can't always make room for armor and artillery with your infantry. All you're really paying for is a DLC race pack for multiplayer Imperial Guard. Relic would have been better off simply releasing it as a DLC pack if they weren't prepared to do the single player properly. They squandered what could have been an epic conclusion to a storyline they had been building up for years, settling for a cheap version of it that leaves the whole experience feeling sour.

End result, you will NEVER get to play this full game!Actual review for The Last Standalone:DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES BUY THE GAME (The Last Standalone) unless you already a know your way around the full game. There is no way to do solo training / practice in game other than being dumped in the thick of it with two other players that will be relying on you to hold up your part of the co-op match, which is impossible when you don't know what you are doing, making it unfair for the other players!This game has the description as Single player, however there is NO single player in the gamme. The only playable option is The Last Stand!I would post this where it should be, as a review for The Last Standalone, but steam will not allow this!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Relic, what the hell were you thinking?Firstly, there is no mention of your original character, i was rather annoyed to see Martellus when i started the campaign so it looks like, your choices in chaos rising do not have any effect on the timeline, other than the whole "Heroes of Aurelia" line. While Cyrus and Tarkus come back, neither have squads and you brought the old game mechanics along for a ride with this too, why the hell does a renegade commander have the ability to call for reinforcements from a starship that dosnt exist? (or at least no mention thus far has been made, considering the fact that youre using a "teleportarium" to move around, im going to assume you dont have a ship - this feels like a ginormous plothole.) Nevermind that they changed the loadout system; energy based abilities for everything - which again, takes your mind away from conserving limited special abilities, while characters like Cyrus still shout "Do not waste what the Emperor provides!" when you order him to use a special attack.While, yes you do still have limited resources now in the form of power and requesition, it dosnt play like the same animal - you have an army beyond the confines of the original game, which imho was much more enjoyable the way it was - this has boiled it down almost into a generic rts clone.Also, what annoyed me the most about this iteration of DOW II - having watched friends and family who are, like me all avid Warhammer fans (I even purchased that trainwreck Fire Warrior, i believed it was a decent game for a while fyi) was the fact that each of the 6 sides campaigns, pretty much played as if you were the same side - just subtle differences like the endings.Other than that, if you've played one side then you dont really need to play the rest, unless youre a cheev-wh*re.Honestly i could go on all day about what i, thus far have personally thought is wrong with this piece of the DOW II title, but ive always had a soft spot for Relic - theyve made some awesome games (*cough* Homeworld *cough*) but i feel that this iteration of Dawn of War is -NOT- one of them.Plainly and simply put; if you prefered Dawn of War II and Dawn of War II: Chaos Rising - dont even bother playing this one, even if you purchased it (like me) as part of a Steam sale package.If you prefer the original Dawn of War and its myriad of expansions, then DOW II: Retribution is totally going to be your cup of tea.- Captain Soban.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												A good game, but lack of optimization means that people with older PCs can't play it very well. Even higher end PCs do have a little bit of trouble with the graphical load, but that's few and far between.The player community, on the other hand, is often toxic to an extreme. Multiplayer is good, but matchmaking is not. The complaints that people have for DOTA 2, especially against Russian players, is very much extant here, especially with regards to teamwork, as well as loadtimes (because for some reason, most Russian players cannot afford decent computers or set their settings to low, and often use vulgar language when asked to cooperate with host requests or to work with teammates. The learning curve is steep, and I have to say I took several hundred hours in Vanilla DOW2 and Chaos Rising to get to some degree of skill, enough to reliably defeat opponents. To be very frank, this is not a newbie friendly game. The micromanagement required to perform well, or at least at any decent standard of play, is quite above the average micromanagement capacity of a newbie. As for ELITE mod, though I have personal misgivings against a mod created by someone who felt that DOW2 wasn't balanced and as such balanced it to suit his own tastes (Which to be honest is enterprising, but reeking utterly of hypocrisy), it is a fun mod to play, even though the community is even tinier than the already small DOW2 community.The campaign, well, is fun at first, but loses its novelty when one compares it to the original DOW2 and Chaos Rising, which have a dedicated and properly fleshed out campaign with multiple choices. The fact that THQ actually reused campaign maps and storylines for each faction is indicative of their slide into mediocrity and bankruptcy - no game designer should be that lazy. Overall, this is a fun game to play. I have put many hours into it, and likely will continue to for the foreseeable future.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
												Where do I start? Unlike Chaos Rising, this is not an expansion of WH40K DOWII. This game stands alone, has a different campaign and last stand. It also has Important DLC content for you competetive types, but I'll get to that later.The Good:+More races = more fun. Yes, you can play the campaign, multiplayer and last stand as Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Orks, Eldar, Tyranids and Chaos. +Same basic game as the others in the series+The campaign continues the story from the first two in the series, but in a method much closer to regular gameplay+Campaign voice acting is decent. I won't say outstanding, but hey, you're not here for voice overs... unless you want to play all the campaigns.+In PVP, your units matter. So does map control. It's not about how fast you build your base, but how well you can micromanage.The Bad:-The system requirements are much higher than those listed. Yes, you can play the game with those specs. I would not recommend it. (unless you like 15 fps)-The campaign missions are the exact same between races. The "motivation" is different, but the missions are the same. -Campaign skills and talents do not always translate to multiplayer-To be truly competetive in multiplayer, you have to buy DLC packs. I'm sorry. There's just no way around it. I know from personal experience that they can be game changers. Pick a favorite race, and get their DLC upgrades. This goes for Last stand as well-Tau only have one unit and he's a DLC for the last stand. You can skin the tau onto the Imperial Guard units if you really want to play as the Tau.Final thoughts:This game is fun and unique. If I had to describe it, I'd call it an RTS with elements of a MOBA. The Dawn of War 2 series as a whole does a good job of bringing the tabletop feel back to the game. It's a bit of a learnig curve, but if you like RTS games in general, I definitely reccomend this one.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												For none-tabletop players: 9 of 10 stars.For all those of you, who love playing the mix of strategy games and RPG's, its an awesome game.You can choose a race like Space Marines (gen-manipulated super soldiers in the heaviest armors you can imagine), orkz (big, green and tons of aggression), the imperial Army ( normal humans, throw-away-units, but like a mass army, they overrun every enemy) and many others.While playing, your units gain experience and level up. So you can raise their stats and change the equipment of every hero in your squad.The game is split up in more or less 15 missions, individualized for each of the races.Otherwise you can play the ,,last stand", where you and 2 other players try to survive 20 waves of enemys.Last aspect of the game is the multiplayer mode, where you can play solo or in team against other players.For tabletop players: 7 of 10 stars.Of course the game is still epic. But there are a few bad mistakes in the game, which let your smile disappear....Much of the equipment isn't codexconform, there are characters and Chapters that doesn't exist, an exterminatus that isn't an exterminatus ((it's an overkill in game.....first thousands of lances, and then a magmabomb which is much bigger than usual)(and although it's an planet with a great flora and fauna, there are no virusbombs)).Ok, this could be called pedantically, but if you know the codex and the rulebook, you will notice theese things wether you like or not...In spite of everything i advise you to buy this game ;)

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												I enjoy playing this game. I have a love for RTS games and grew tired of the old medieval era, even though that's a favorite theme of mine when it comes to video games. Though the space side of an RTS that is more focused on squad tactics and implements heroes is an excellent addition to the genre. Most RTS games are simply "a numbers game" meaning who ever has the largest force will win. However, this game allows you to win fights against larger forces. Being able to use squad/hero abilities allows you to be more versatile on the virtual battlefield. If you know what you're doing and can think before you make your move, prep your assaults/defensive positions, then you'll win without a doubt. Scout the terrain and pick the best positions available.P.S.The boss fights are pretty epic too. Not to mention being able to loot wargear in game and select rewards to upgrade your heroes and honorary units is pretty slick too. It gives the game a personal touch.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												It all started when our protagonist, Civ 5, woke up in a pumpkin patch. It was the fourth time it had happened. Feeling ridiculously exasperated, Civ 5 groped a sock, thinking it would make him feel better (but as usual, it did not). Unexpectedly, he realized that his beloved ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was missing! Immediately he called his friend, Leroy Jenkins. Civ 5 had known Leroy Jenkins for (plus or minus) one million years, the majority of which were sassy ones. Leroy Jenkins was unique. He was intelligent though sometimes a little... dimwitted. Civ 5 called him anyway, for the situation was urgent.Leroy Jenkins picked up to a very happy Civ 5. Leroy Jenkins calmly assured him that most koalas yawn before mating, yet otters usually earnestly grimace *after* mating. He had no idea what that meant; he was only concerned with distracting Civ 5. Why was Leroy Jenkins trying to distract Civ 5? Because he had snuck out from Civ 5's with the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth only four days prior. It was a saucy little ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth... how could he resist?It didn't take long before Civ 5 got back to the subject at hand: his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins sighed. Relunctantly, Leroy Jenkins invited him over, assuring him they'd find the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Civ 5 grabbed his desk and disembarked immediately. After hanging up the phone, Leroy Jenkins realized that he was in trouble. He had to find a place to hide the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and he had to do it thoughtfully. He figured that if Civ 5 took the truck, he had take at least eleven minutes before Civ 5 would get there. But if he took the ♥♥♥? Then Leroy Jenkins would be alarmingly screwed.Before he could come up with any reasonable ideas, Leroy Jenkins was interrupted by seven abrasive aligators that were lured by his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins sighed; 'Not again', he thought. Feeling frustrated, he thoughtfully reached for his mitten and aptly backhanded every last one of them. Apparently this was an adequate deterrent--the discouraged critters began to scurry back toward the thicket, squealing with discontent. He exhaled with relief. That's when he heard the ♥♥♥ rolling up. It was Civ 5.----o0o---- As he pulled up, he felt a sense of urgency. He had had to make an unscheduled stop at Wal-Mart to pick up a 12-pack of pencils, so he knew he was running late. With a calculated leap, Civ 5 was out of the ♥♥♥ and went indiscriminately jaunting toward Leroy Jenkins's front door. Meanwhile inside, Leroy Jenkins was panicking. Not thinking, he tossed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth into a box of mittens and then slid the box behind his piano. Leroy Jenkins was concerned but at least the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was concealed. The doorbell rang.'Come in,' Leroy Jenkins sassily purred. With a careful push, Civ 5 opened the door. 'Sorry for being late, but I was being chased by some funny-smelling maniac in a Vette,' he lied. 'It's fine,' Leroy Jenkins assured him. Civ 5 took a seat vaguely close to where Leroy Jenkins had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. Leroy Jenkins cringed trying unsuccessfully to hide his nervousness. 'Uhh, can I get you anything?' he blurted. But Civ 5 was distracted. Without warning, Leroy Jenkins noticed a selfish look on Civ 5's face. Civ 5 slowly opened his mouth to speak.'...What's that smell?'Leroy Jenkins felt a stabbing pain in his butt when Civ 5 asked this. In a moment of disbelief, he realized that he had hidden the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth right by his oscillating fan. 'Wh-what? I don't smell anything..!' A lie. A insensitive look started to form on Civ 5's face. He turned to notice a box that seemed clearly out of place. 'Th-th-those are just my grandma's mittens from when she used to have pet bunnies. She, uh...dropped 'em by here earlier'. Civ 5 nodded with fake acknowledgement...then, before Leroy Jenkins could react, Civ 5 randomly lunged toward the box and opened it. The ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was plainly in view.Civ 5 stared at Leroy Jenkins for what what must've been four seconds. Unexpectedly, Leroy Jenkins groped wildly in Civ 5's direction, clearly desperate. Civ 5 grabbed the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth and bolted for the door. It was locked. Leroy Jenkins let out a eccentric chuckle. 'If only you hadn't been so protective of that thing, none of this would have happened, Civ 5,' he rebuked. Leroy Jenkins always had been a little insensitive, so Civ 5 knew that reconciliation was not an option; he needed to escape before Leroy Jenkins did something crazy, like... start chucking mittens at him or something. All of a sudden, he gripped his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth tightly and made a dash toward the window, diving headlong through the glass panels.Leroy Jenkins looked on, blankly. 'What the hell? That seemed excessive. The other door was open, you know.' Silence from Civ 5. 'And to think, I varnished that window frame nine days ago...it never ends!' Suddenly he felt a tinge of concern for Civ 5. 'Oh. You ..okay?' Still silence. Leroy Jenkins walked over to the window and looked down. Civ 5 was gone.----o0o---- Just yonder, Civ 5 was struggling to make his way through the pumpkin patch behind Leroy Jenkins's place. Civ 5 had severely hurt his arm during the window incident, and was starting to lose strength. Another pack of feral aligators suddenly appeared, having caught wind of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. One by one they latched on to Civ 5. Already weakened from his injury, Civ 5 yielded to the furry onslaught and collapsed. The last thing he saw before losing consciousness was a buzzing horde of aligators running off with his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth.About seven hours later, Civ 5 awoke, his butt throbbing. It was dark and Civ 5 did not know where he was. Deep in the humid desert, Civ 5 was abundantly lost. A few minutes later, he remembered that his ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth was taken by the aligators. But at that point, he was just thankful for his life. That's when, to his horror, a oversized aligator emerged from the cornfield. It was the alpha aligator. Civ 5 opened his mouth to scream but was cut short when the aligator sunk its teeth into Civ 5's face. With a faint groan, the life escaped from Civ 5's lungs, but not before he realized that he was a failure.Less than two miles away, Leroy Jenkins was entombed by anguish over the loss of the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth. 'MY PRECIOUS!!' he cried, as he reached for a sharpened spoon. With a heroic thrust, he buried it deeply into his neck. As the room began to fade to black, he thought about Civ 5... wishing he had found the courage to tell him that he loved him. But he would die alone that day. All that remained was the ♥♥♥♥♥ of truth that had turned them against each other, ultimately causing their demise. And as the dew on melancholy sappling branches began to reflect the dawn's reddish glare, all that could be heard was the chilling cry of distant aligators, desecrating all things sacred to virtuous men, and perpetuating an evil that would reign for centuries to come. Our heroes would've lived unhappily ever after, but they were too busy being dead. So, no one lived forever after, the end. :'(

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												For none-tabletop players: 9 of 10 stars.For all those of you, who love playing the mix of strategy games and RPG's, its an awesome game.You can choose a race like Space Marines (gen-manipulated super soldiers in the heaviest armors you can imagine), orkz (big, green and tons of aggression), the imperial Army ( normal humans, throw-away-units, but like a mass army, they overrun every enemy) and many others.While playing, your units gain experience and level up. So you can raise their stats and change the equipment of every hero in your squad.The game is split up in more or less 15 missions, individualized for each of the races.Otherwise you can play the ,,last stand", where you and 2 other players try to survive 20 waves of enemys.Last aspect of the game is the multiplayer mode, where you can play solo or in team against other players.For tabletop players: 7 of 10 stars.Of course the game is still epic. But there are a few bad mistakes in the game, which let your smile disappear....Much of the equipment isn't codexconform, there are characters and Chapters that doesn't exist, an exterminatus that isn't an exterminatus ((it's an overkill in game.....first thousands of lances, and then a magmabomb which is much bigger than usual)(and although it's an planet with a great flora and fauna, there are no virusbombs)).Ok, this could be called pedantically, but if you know the codex and the rulebook, you will notice theese things wether you like or not...In spite of everything i advise you to buy this game ;)

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Being a die hard DOWI fan, It took me a long while to warm up to the changes they made with DOWII, however now that they've stopped bombarding us with mini DLC's I decided to bite the bullet, get the entire game and give it a go.Single player campaign.Very action RPG very well done with a star map allowing you to pick your missions mostly, and a different campaign for each race.Action RPG is not really my thing, but its still nice to play this on occasion.Co-op campaign.Not tried it, its nice that its here though.Single player Skirmish.This is more my style customize your game and experiment to find your favourite tactics and strategy.DOWII has taken a very different approach to RTS than DOW I, essentially you have less units, no buildings, and more micro, all ideas I thought where bad, but they have produced good and distinctive tactic oriented game, the action feels alot mor intense here but if you can keep up it is very satisfying when you succeed. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.Multi-player Skirmish.This is where things really heat up, and this is my favourite mode, be warned as with many game you will need to practice VS the AI before attempting to take on other players, but the huge arrange of units and sides and the beautifully done maps, animations etc all contribute to making this an unforgettable RTS experience. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.One of my favourite RTS games, recommended if you like both ACTION RPG or RTS or just W40K   - 8.5/10One wish - that they included the Tau, fortunately there's a mod for that.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												8.5/10 (-1pt. bcause of the lagg that is encountered sometimes and -0.5pt. because people will still compare it with the first game of the series... including me <-call it just a personal preference)Well, even tho the lagg in the multiplayer games can become an issue (multiplayer being a peer to peer thinghie), the game is pretty badass. Yeah, it's not the first DOW where u spammed units until your enemies would die. Yeah it's not Starcraft 2 (and for the love of the Emperor, stop comparing the two) where you need the dexterity of a piano player; but it's a game where tactics and strategy blend nicely. learn to abuse the retreat button in multiplayer. The learning curve is kinda steep, especially against veteran players BUT (and that's a big but) once you get the hang of it, you will realize that there aren't two games exactly the same. Let's take for ex the orks. Deadly at close range, with the right upgrades, will♥♥♥♥♥♥anything from afar too. A little word of advice for the new players tho: use space marines/force commander. The strategy is simple: run, conquer the requisition points, retreat, heal, harass, overcome and overpower. The MOD that people talk about it's not that important. The title is solid as it is. The only question that remains is... are you a loyalist or a traitorous scum?

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Where do I start? The Dawn of War series has always been one of my fav franchises as a 40k fan, and Dawn of War 2 Retribution has been my most played so far. The game leaps from the more mainstream aspects of stragety gaming, like any Relic game does, and goes straight for the battles and action, forcing you and your opponent to tackle over land and territory of the map in order to get resource and Victory Points. Many 40k fans complain about the games small army and squad size, being that the average Space Marine Tactical Squad goes in a maximum squad of 3-4, personally I was dissapointed on first hearing this, but now I mostly enjoy the tactical flexibility it gives to your squadrons.; this game has no base-building, and it requires you to keep your squads and units alive if you want the advantage over your opponent, giving you capabilities such as a 'retreat' system and a unique 'cover system' for you to take minimum casualties. Dawn of War II has always been a more tactical-soaked game than mass armies, though great online 3v3 games can be insane anyway in terms of relentless fighting over Victory Points.The single-player is the games weakest element. Although it gives you 7 different racse, each with a unique story, the gameplay is not at all replayable, since all the races experience the exact same missions, and a rare amount of unique dialogue interactions, which was very dissapointing.For anyone interested in a strategy game that exits from the mainstream base-building and isn't too interested in the Company of Heroes franchise, give Dawn of War a run for your money on the Steam Sales. I'd reccomend this to 40k fans who can tolerate the small squad sizes.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2012
												This is a great RTS, and the campaign is full of story and action. Great character designs, and I loved the number of available races. Last Stand is GREAT for friends, pick a race hero and survive. Spectacular gladiator-inspired game mode, coupled with the individuality of each hero, all the pros and cons, I always have a blast. Dawn of War II is a must-have for any RTS group player, Warhammer fan, science fiction fan, or just somebody looking to have a good time, for a long time. You will NOT get bored for quite a long time, it is a very fulfilling game with more than enough to entertain you for months.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												Disclaimer: Definitely buy on sale in the bundle so you can play DoW 2 (Vanilla) and Chaos Rising.PositivesOut of the Dawn of War 2 series, Retribution is my least favourite. That being said I enjoyed the Space Marine campaign, and a bit of the Eldar.NegativesOther than that it's essentially copy / paste campaign with a different race (skin) and non canon story.As for the multiplayer, I've not yet tried it beyond Last Stand. Which Last Stand is fine, but definitely not something I'd keep playing after I get the achievements.There is also a weird sound bug which the first two Dawn of War 2's did not have, which can cause your game to crash, and there is also an achievement campaign bug if you lose steam / internet connection which corrupts the whole file and any with that name apparently and never allows you to get the completion achievement.In addition if you think you're buying all the DLC content if you purchase the DOW  Franchise Pack, think again. They exclude the Overlord hero for Last Stand, and instead only include that in the package which has Space Marine, A COMPLETELY DIFFERENT GAME that is has no function with.ResultI do NOT recommend this game at full price or purchased alone, but the dow 2 bundle, or rather buy the sega collection that includes the Last Stand overlord and Space Marine.Don't be mislead like I was by a stupid marketing ploy meant to rip you off.Rating for Space Marine campaign because of previous two, 9/10.Overall rating for game because of the bugs / crashes, and the  misleading rip off for Overlord and bundles.2/10.Definitely buy on sale in the bundle so you can play DoW 2 (Vanilla) and Chaos Rising.

number of helpful: 21 of 43 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Dawn of War II is a huge step backwards from the original Dawn of War series (winter assault, dark crusade, soulstorm). Why they ever decided to throw base building and big-scale wars out of the window in a strategy game is beyond me. Command and conquer 4 made the same massive mistake as all of the Dawn fo War II series did. No more big battles, no more base building, no more really epic units battling it out, no more epic long games. Just you and a handful of squads versus an enemy with a handful of squads in games that usually don't last very long. There's not much room for strategizing and diversification with such a small pool of things to do stuff with. The entire game feels more like you're participating in a few small-scale guerilla warfare missions rather than a real epic war. Graphics and sounds aside, which are actually pretty decent and a reasonable improvement over the original series, I really cannot recommend this to anyone who's a fan of the original series. If you are new to Dawn of war in its entirety, then sure, you can give this a shot. It can be an ok time sink. But in my opinion, you'd still be better off just going with the original Dawn of War anyway, rather than this one. Only the campaign is reasonably fun to play due to the storyline. but even then many of the things in the campaign (including the missions themselves) constantly repeat no matter which race you play it through with next, so it doesn't give you any reason to play it again after you played it out once.TL;DR - Overall, I just don't recommend it at all, nor do I recommend any of the other Dawn of War II games. I would much rather point people to Dawn of War: Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. Even when Dawn of War II isn't compared to anything, it still only reaches a 5/10 rating in my opinion, at the very best. An 'ok' time sink, but not much else.Trying to be innovative and new is all well and good, but that does not warrant completely annihilating a working (and fun) formula, which the original series was most popular for.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Cool graphics and "on the edge" artstyle but that's all it's got going.Unit control is clunky, they won't obey you and their fihgting movesets are repetitive.No micromanagement to speak of, send unit X to counter unit Y and click on its ability for maximum damage. There really isn't an explanation about damage or armour types other than "unit X can beat unit Y, Z and W".=fighting is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥br>What about basebuilding? There is none, and that might be ok, several games manage to stay fresh without basebuilding.But here you've got nothing to do, you capture the objectives and it only goes downhill from there, there's no "escalation"- you're scraping for cash to get a unit early game and you're scraping for cash by lategame, except this time you do that even more because later units are more costy.Rpg system? Sounds amazing on paper, in reality it just means you gotta grind to get better.It's a worse game compared to dow1 not because dow1 was more "traditonal" (although pretty groundbreaking for its time) but because dow1 knew what it was, dow2 on the other hand tries to be company of heroes, an rpg and an arena game all in one. But fails at the most important thing: being fun.Do you recommend this game?Only if you hate older graphics, fanatically disdain basebuilding or are legally forbidden from coming 10 feet near anything that resembles dawn of war 1 but still deeply crave dawn of war 1's sweet♥♥♥♥♥Otherwise? Pirate/buy on sale the first entry: it has everything, and what it doesn't have can be added through mods.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												The most recent Warhammer 40k stratigy game. Will continue to allow online play after the other DoW2 interations die due to the ending of Games for Windows Live. Focuses heavily on squad combat, with resource aqusition reduced to territory control; the only way to get what you need is to hold ground. Results in a far more enjoyable tactical experience than games like Star Craft 2, where holding ground and tactical expasion is much less important relatively. Factions are not all perfectly balanced, but there's a good number to choose from (not as many as in the final DoW 1 expansion, but I'm not sure if you can still play DoW 1 online).Gameplay: 


YouTube™ Video: Glance: Dawn of War 2 Retribution (No GFWL!) 

			Views: 35		

			The first two games of the Warhammer 40k Dawn of War 2 PC franchise will literally become unplayable when GFWL goes down. Retribution, the second expansion to DoW2, WILL KEEP WORKING!

												having problems with this game. despite buying the base Dawn of War II Retribution, i can only play in the LastStandAlone game mode, with both multiplayer and campaign greyed out. it says both on the store page and in my library that I own the game, so why can't I play two of it's modes? Having tried to get the issue solved through the offical support page, but they have not answered the ticket I submitted last year...I will happily admit that the LastStandAlone is great fun having sunk in more hours in a row than I care to admit, but it is severly hampered (in my opinion) by it's lack of diverse maps, as there are only two (that I know of) in the game currently.If these iusses were fixed, and I hope they will be, then I would happily give this game a 9/10. But alas, due to issues i can only give it a 3.3/10 (as the LastStandAlone is way too much fun, but is only 1/3rd of the game I purchased D:  ). content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												I find it difficult to enjoy Retribution, but I will recommend it with certain reservations. One the one hand, the small unit tactics and powerful feel of 2 and Chaos Rising has been preserved. On the other, there's no actual difference between campaigns. If I use Imperial Guard, for example, the campaign is utterly identical to the Tyranid or Eldar campaigns with the obvious exception of who I'm actually playing as. Most of the campaign missions are exercises in flooding the map with as many troops as possible in the vain hope of killing the massive monster with more health than a tank before it squishes everyone on the field. One late game mission comes to mind wherein a massive biological nightmare is attacking an unarmed APC that conveniently has your only way out on board. This thing has more health than most armored vehicles and can near instantly kill most infantry sent at it, and due to the mission itself, infantry is all you can send at it. One early mission has the player party of cardboard boxes intercepting and destroying a light armored convoy with no anti armor weapons avaliable due to how early in the game it is. Eventually the only solution is to barricade the exits with gun turrets and hope massed infantry fire will kill the vehicles. The best mission by far is roughly middle of the game, during which the player and party revisit a location from Chaos Rising and finally put an end to the big baddy from that game. This mission was certainly frustrating for a number of reasons, but it added a certain sense of closure to the whole plot line that wasn't present in Chaos Rising. IN short, this game is rather flawed but certainly playable if grinding is acceptable.
