content:
Posted: April 9, 2011
												Orks, Eldars and Tyranids, oh my!DoW2:Retribution is the third installment of the Dawn of War 2 saga and a succesfull one at that.The campaign, one for each race, got a respectable playtime and also extremely fun to play with a friend!However DoW2 is an RTS at heart, and thus have MP as focus.DoW2 sticks out alot compared to fellow RTS game of making a base and mass produce units. Here you only have one building that will do all of it for you. And for every loving warhammer nerd out there, this game is a must have! Unless you don't like RTS games.Things like using the terrain for cover, or using a force push to send your own or the enemies troops to a location all makes DOW2 a unique RTS game that focus much more on you to take care of every squad you have. Retreat when necessary, roll in a tank to smash through walls when also necessary!With 6 Races, the game comes fairly balanced for an RTS. Should be considered purchase for the MP possibilities. 4/5

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Ok, well first of all, I come from playing Dawn of war 1 and its expansions, I skipped DOW2 and Chaos Rising. That being said, this game is very different. For multiplayer I would say this game is excellent, if you can get good enough to beat the skilled people who play. Quite a learning curve unless you're really good at RTS's .Also, the Last Stand Mode was amazing. In my opinion the Campaign was quite weak, but I suppose that can be excused by trying to create a storyline for 6 races. However, Dawn of War 1 dark crusade did this with 7 races and made an amazing game, with a decent story. One of my major complaints about this game is that it takes FOREVER to kill a unit, and more often than not, they just rout (run away super fast so you can't catch them) and regroup. I realize that does add some strategy to the game, but overall the battles are just not as fun or as dramatic as in DOW 1.So here's the summary:Gameplay:Singleplayer: 4/10Multiplayer: 8/10Graphics and Sounds are both about 7/10. I know people will say that i'm wrong with this, but I really liked the cartoony-but-cool graphics from DOW1 and the sound as well. This is, after all, my opinion. Anyhoo, that's what I think, thx for reading.

Even when you’re stomping a noob into their corner of the map. Out-♥♥♥♥’n-Standing in my opinion. I’d say some people are even scared♥♥♥♥♥♥less to attempt to play versus in multiplayer anymore.It’s a game where only the hardest players are forged or break down and their ego, shatter to pieces.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												Why can't I play as blue man group in anything but Last Stand?No bolter ♥♥♥♥♥es? No bdsm space elves? I mean honestly after trying to play the game I now know why most people ♥♥♥♥ing hate it. It is a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥moba version of the original. Everything takes an eternity to build/destroy and the game feels like everything is coated in congealed cosmoline. You can't even set the game speed. It does nothing well that it is attempting. I dislike almost everything about the game. Even with such little time played on it I can't get a refund for this pile of clunky reskinned CoH. Guess that is what I get for buying something on sale  and just now get around to play it 3 years later.The only positive comment I have is that the Tyranids are playable. That is honestly it. I highly recommend the first Dawn of War over this. Or really any other game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
												While still not a solid RTS, it fixes all of the stupid that was in DOW2 and made even worse in Chaos Rising. You still have heros, but you also get units, like an actual strategy game, rather than walking a bunch of chattering dolls around (or in the case of CR, balancing a terribly designed karma system). The campaign is comparatively short but playable by each race and provides reward choices that aren't throwaway trash items 90% of the time. Unfortunately, the campaign hero units only go to level 10 and there's a much more limited selection of equipment. Ultimately a much better game than DOW2 and CR, but too short. This still isn't anything like the original DOW - so if you need a 40k RTS fix, get a copy of Soulstorm and grab the Ultimate Apocalypse mod.

												Перед нами детище студии Relic и ныне покойной THQ:Warhammer 40.000 Dawn of War 2 Retribution.Я бы хотел начать свой обзор с сюжета и описать его по подробнее, но так как его нет (об этом позже) перейдём сразу к деталям:1)Графика: на графон разрабы явно забили и не стали ничего менять со времён выхода Dawn of War 2.2)Звук: среднего качества, вобщем радует неочень.3)Геймплей: нуден и глуп, это САМЫЙ большой минус игры4)Сюжет:теперь по подробнее, нам наконец дали сыграть за кого-то кроме Кровавых воронов, нам обещали много интересных компаний.Что я про это скажу?Да♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥там был, компании шаблонные, тоесть одни и те же миссии только в разном порядке и разными диалогами(зависит от расы за которую мы играем) так что провал и тоже минус.5)Мультиплеер:1)Битвы-очень долгие и не экшоновые, постоянные лаги из-за людей у которых комп♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ но они выкручивают графон на максимум(синхронизация проводица по самым лагерным) так что хрень.                        2)Режим арены-интересная вещь, за ней можно скоротать несколько часов описывать больно не буду, но приедается он быстро.Итог: игра является эталоном того как нельзя делать и игры, так что НЕ РЕКОМЕНДУЮ И УМОЛЯЮ НЕ ТРАТЕ НА НЕЁ СВОИ ДЕНЬГИ!!!!!!!!

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Ok, I normally can't be bothered to write a review, but there's a few things you should know before paying anything other than 75% off for this game. I'll keep it simple.Single player campaign feels like a rushed afterthought. No more cool planetary backdrops or watching your ship jump into a new system. Now you get a static map and dumbed down levelling system. DoW II is better if you want single player, unless you simply HAVE to play as Orks/Eldar etc.But wait! Multiplayer is what it's all about anyway right? It could be, but seeing as finding a public game that doesn't boot you out after the countdown reaches zero is next to impossible, you're limited to private matches. The Last Stand works fine, but if you only want to play that you can buy it seperately anyway.Overall it's a shame, as DoW II is good fun, especially in multiplayer, but without the ability to actually play public matches, all Retribution really brings to the table is a new race to play as. On your own. If you want a solid multiplayer strategy game with an active community and servers that (mostly) work, get CoH instead.

												This is not a good game.I love the last stand gamemode and the fact that Tyranids are now a thing, but that's where my love for this game ends.I'll start right off with the absolute worst thing about this game: Tau are DLC and, soon enough, you'll have to pay for the Necron DLC as well, although for the time being it is free.What the ♥♥♥♥!?I can play those two in DARK CRUSADE if I want to! You shouldn't have to pay extra for content that was IN PREVIOUS GAMES!The Tau and Necrons were my favourite factions, and now I have to pay *extra money* to play as them because the publishers are such bloody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.And what's more, they completely ruined skirmish mode! The gameplay is entirely different and it's the kind of thing I'd expect from something that ISN'T part of the DoW series. It completely deviates from all the games before it, and it sucks.They also got rid of that sandbox-y campaign and it's now linear.Long story short: If you want to play Dawn of War, play Dark Crusade or Soulstorm. Not this pathetic excuse for a Dawn of War title.

												I kinda have to say no to this expansion. I like the fact, there are 6 fractions(I only played two so far) but the fact is, than none of them got me wanting to play more. You bring some units and on top of that you can buy more units, so you do not get that "personal" relationship, with your units as you did with your heroes.All in all, I do not recommend this expansion.5/10

Posted: September 18, 2015
												Actually one of the worst DoW games I've ever played. See DoW should resonate two things: Incrediable heroes, and incredible single player experience. This game.... neither. The heros aren't "incredible" by any means. They lack the personality and story lines from the previous DoW's. In DoW 2, for example, I loved Aviticus's character. His **** everything attitude, his "no males, no females, just soldier's" look on gender, and not just his story or just him, I liked all of the characters, they were all unique and intriguing... this game... literally.... is just copy paste mentality gone too far. The campaign consists of the EXACT....SAME....LEVELS..... OVER.... AND OVER..... AND OVER..... NO MATTER WHICH RACE YOU PICK. SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"Well how can that be? The Space Marines have to fight a giant demon for the end where they and chaos are the only races that ever go to that planet at that time"Man ♥♥♥♥ your logic, we're LITERALLY gonna put in a 30 second narration that says durring the tyrinid campaign "Yeah that demon is bad news we better just break the space/time continuium and make a battle that should never have happened happen.... cause we dont want to spend the time or effort actually writting a ♥♥♥♥ing story that makes sense for each individual race.""Well fine...ok... thats one race.... but what about the other's?"Repeat my last comment but input the name of whichever race you want."What about the battle sisters? the necrons? the Tau?"We'll have one sentence of dialauge that mentions each race and how we chalk up their lack of existance to "they arent around." But the tau can be a playable race in the Last Stand Stand Alone game... just no story or any real relevence at all."So... you took the time and effort and money to develop the Tau models, and weapons, and unit actions.... and then just said.... '♥♥♥♥ them and their story?'"YepDawn of war 2 and Dawn of war 2 Chaos Rising were a little dissappointing but I would still recomend them. They were very fun and surprisingly had decent character story and plot. This game is terrible. And if you want to get the game just for "The Last Stand" game mode, dont.... you can get it stand alone.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Seemed like a good idea for $13.75 with all the DLC. However, it seemed that Relic Entertainment didn't provide any updates to resolve the slow load times or co-op multiplayer issues. It could be due to the free weekend overload but I doubt it.PROS1. ThemeInteresting story about the Blood Ravens, Exterminatus and how all the different factions play a role in the overarching story. I like how they made sure all the races melded into one main story.2. Wargear & SkillsI like the customisation of skills and equipment. The 3 different skill trees (Combat, Health and Energy) add a small change in playstyle.3. Multi-Race CampaignNice to know that each race has its own campaign.4. Last StandFun. Gets a little boring playing the same match though.CONS1. Load TimesFor some reason, the game requires one to wait for 2 whole minutes before one can start a map and another 2 whole minutes before one can close the game. This is a major downer for me. For a 2011 game, it is quite odd.2. Server IssuesWhile trying to play Last Stand, the game hangs after the countdown finishes. It is only during some rare occasion that a game starts up.3. RepetitiveControl your leader and his honour guard, attack or defend, break open crates, capture points and bases. Every single location seems to be exactly the same. The only major difference tends to be a boss fight, other than that there is nothing unique.4. Overly-Simplified CampaignThe way you capture the bases at fixed locations is quite odd. It's as if a base was magically planned to be there. Sometimes, the bases are redundant as your hero can just summon units. E.g. Hive Lord calling in Genestealers5. CoverUnsure if it's even necessary. While it is possible to hide behind cover, there isn't a real need to.6. AIThe AI is just silly, it can't path around simple blockages or auto-attack enemies. E.g. Genestealers don't know how to go around an obstacle to attack. You have to break the obstacle with your Hive Lord before the Genestealers know how to attack. 7. Unit SupplyI really do not understand why you have to capture a supply building. I can understand capturing Requisition and Power but the whole idea of a satellite dish providing supply seems odd. The theme just doesn't sync with the idea of unit supply.8. Redundant Heavy UnitsYou don't really have to destroy bases in the campaign, so it makes you wonder why you need vehicles/heavies at all. You hardly see turrets in except in the early stages of the campaign and even then you can deal with the turrets without heavies.9. Resource CratesYou have to manually Right Click on the Requisition and Power that appear after a crate is broken. It's quite tedious and does not provide any fun. Why couldn't they just automatically collect the resources when they fall out? The same problem applies to dropped Accessories and Hero Equipment.10. AbilitiesLots of visual effects but no impact. a. The casting is not smooth. There is a long windup before certain abilities trigger, which may result in misses. E.g. Hive Lord's Plasma Barrageb. Inaccurate E.g. Doombolt from the Chaos SorcerorThe best executed abilities seem to be those that do not require aiming and are centred on the hero. E.g. AOE heal or Doomblast.11. Last Stand Lack of DiversityWhy can't we use all the commanders? Why is it restricted to 1 from each race?NEUTRAL1. Unit DesignI'm a bit aghast at how some units were designed. This is a personal preference but I thought I ought to write it out. E.g. Tyranid ranged units (Termagaunts, Hive Lord) and their "hose gun" concept.SUGGESTIONS1. Ping Column for MultiplayerI can't see the ping to another player. I would prefer a lag-free game instead of a 200-400ms lag game.

												Retribution isn't an AAA title but it's very good. It manages to capture a lot of the Warhammer feel while focusing on micro-based gameplay. The game is also more friendly toward mods than the previous Games for Windows Live entries in the series.The game needs some balancing work in some areas (which may or may not ever get done), and it has a memory leak issue on load times. Also the DLC is generally not worth the money.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												Retribution is quite different to DoW2 and DoW2 Chaos Rising; there are 6 races each with their own campaign - but the campaigns are only slightly different in terms of dialogue and enemy. You will still visit the same planets. The game also added a different dimension to your hero squads by giving your resources to buy units. These units are cheap cannon fodder for the most part. The loot & RPG elements of DoW2 and Chaos Rising have been drastically dumbed down for the worse. I would recommend this but the game has crashed twice on me in the first 2 hours. Played the first level of each campaign to play with the units, but overall not worth me fighting through the crashing. Coould be because of Windows 10.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2011
												I came back to DOW2: Retribution after a long hiatus and I can honestly say: I would NOT recommend this game to anyone.  It is a poor and feels like a rush and sloppy continuation of the series.Pros:1. You can play 6 of the Warhammer 40K races in campaign and multiplayer2. Co Op campaign with a friend3. custom color your army for multiplayer4. new DLC skins for troops and Last Stand5. The Last Stand is funCons:1. The multiplayer takes far to long to find a ranked game.  Likewise, there are very few NonRanked games avaialble at times.2. The races are always unbalanced, despite the amount of updates released.3. The units LEVEL UP makes it impossible to fight back or even start a counter attack near the game's end.  This only makes the opposing side quit early or just lose interst in playing any further.4. Campaign is linear and has the same story arch, with no variation for either race.  Every Map has no freedom of movement, which forces players to go in ONE direction.  This was never a factor in the previous DOW II installments.5. People who bought hte Collector's Edition were cheated out of their money for rubbish cards and a small poster.  For the same price I expect an art book, a soundtrack or more.  I purchased the C.E. upon pre-order and I was utterly disgusted by what was offered.  Their advertisement for the items was very misleading.6. Units are expensive, you spend more time managing them than playing the game.Too add: I have been giving this game so many benefits of a doubt that I just finally said, "it fails". A Game is ment to be fun and exciting, DOWII: Retribution kills that by making you feel RUSHED, TENSE, & ANGRY. It takes a lot to get me mad, and this game has pushed that button. Other RTS games were challanging but at least they were fun and had preferable replay value. DOW: Retribution is so unbalanced it's annoying. Every race is expensive, even for weaker units. You spend more time trying to amass resources that you when you finally buy that 400 gold +250 Wood super unit, when it dies out just 10 seconds after purchase, I just say "F@ck it!" Dawn of War 2 Retribution is a poor sequel to its predecessor, Dawn of War, in terms of multiplayer, unit management, combat and most importantly FUN. I have more fun at the table top than I do with this...thing. (It doesn't even deserve to be a game, let alone have a Warhammer 40,000 theme attached to it.) This game feels more like it was rushed and lacks any sign of polish, enjoyment or a supportive staff.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I'm not sure what to think of this game. When I heard that there were different campaigns for all the playable factions, I was hyped. I thought it would be reminiscent of Warcraft in that they'd all tie into each other - nope. They're all the same missions, just with your faction. They all play differently, but not to the extent of Dawn of War 1. You never really "feel" like your faction is all that different from the others.Speaking of Dawn of War 1, Retribution really feels like it wants to recapture the massive, awesome battles that took place there. Does it succeed? Not really, no. All it did was take the squad-based mechanics of 2 and took the scale of 1 to make some overly-simplistic, watered down mess. And despite what Orks may say, "bigger" isn't always "best" - the game doesn't seem to know what to do with big armies, so if you're at a choke point or narrow walkway your units will kind of just crowd around and get stuck. That is INCREDIBLY frustrating. Be an RTS or a squad-tactics game, you can't be both.And I don't know if this is just me, but I have a hard time telling some of the units apart. In DoW1 it's never an issue because the lighting was better and each unit just seemed more unique.Overall, this isn't a bad game, just a disappointing one. Some people may not feel the same way I did about some of these things, but I personally just found it to be a frustrating experience.

content:
Posted: February 22
												This game makes a feeble attempt at solving the massive issues with DoWII, and fails. I had so much hope that this title would live up to the DoWI-series games (Dark Crusade, Soulstorm, etc), but was left completely disappointed. The battles may be slightly larger, but you are not able to "build a massive army" as the advertising claims. It, just like DoWII, tries to be both and RTS and an RPG, but fails at being either of them fully. It has the same boring, linear levels, the same short, flat storytelling, and the same overall lack of tactical depth and complexity that we have seen from the DoWI-series games. Hell, even the "campaign customized for your favorite race" isn't even really true. Every single race has the same campaign, just reskinned with minor differences. I'm glad I got this on sale instead of full price, because it is *NOT* worth full price.I know the fanboys are going to whine at me about how DoWII is sooooo much more like the tabletop, and to that I have one question: does it NEED to be like the tabletop to be GOOD?

												I DONT RECOMMEND THIS GAME FOR DAWN OF WAR 1 FANS. this game is decent as a separate game, but it claims to be  from the dawn of war name but it PLAYS NOTHING LIKE DOW1!.ill number down the reasons.IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN ANOTHER GAME entirely.1-lack of variety the units types are significally numbered down for example Space marines(expansion included) had about 17 units, now is numbed again down whit only 8 or so. also DOW used to have 9 races(whit expansions)  DOW2 whit expansion has the grand total of only 6......2-There is no builder unit and beacuse of that there are no building to be build, you just buy them from your HQ which numbs the game down into just a tactical stratey game inteads of a hydrid RTS that was DoW1. you cant longet build turrets, barrack etc or  keep unlocking technologys like a RTS should be and DoW was.3-The special kills that used to be so prevalent in DoW1 are almost missing in DoW2.4- Squad size and equipment selection is also numbed down. what was a Space marine whit a squad size of 10, is now fully upgraded in DoW 2 only size 4. in DoW1 you could have different weapons add ons in the same squad, for example a Space marine squad whit two plasmas and 2 bazookas, this is no longer true in DoW2 you ca only equip one add on and equip it to only 1 squad member.5- DoW1 where you captured resource points and build energy at your base,. in DOW2 you capture bot on the field (resources and energy) and cant no longer build a turret to defend the command points.6- No longer have multiple heroes instead you choose from only 3 available ones at start. that will determine how you play... or so they claim they basically fight in a bunch of units. Those are the major diferences whit all of this changes DOW2 feels like a capture the flag game just taking a point to be taken back later and retaken by you again, there little about strategy here basically go whit your entire units in one big bunch and take point after point and battle agains another big bunch of units doings the same. there basically no strategy here.   They tried to mix the excelent system of Company of heroes whit some DoW dashed in there. if only they did it right in COH you  took command of points 3 to be expecific (gas,ammo and  the star thingy) but they needed to be linked up whit the base in order to receive you resources. you could have a unit take a strategic point between the connecting points and cut off their resources from them enteriley by breaking the chain, by doing that they manage to have a fast but STRATEGIC game and here is not the case in DOW2 it feels like and asymetrical DOTA.

content:
Posted: February 4
												This game is fun if you are into MOBAs or ARPGs. But if you are looking for a good actuall RTS game or the succesor of the greatest game of all time, this is not one of those. The only positive thing I can say: good graphicsWhat I really really hate about the game:-retreat function-no way to stop the retreat halfway-no view range on strategic points and power noded-no ability to place listening posts on your strat points-victory controll point system-lack of bases-vanilla game was so poorly balanced you kinda had to play the elite mod, banshees could jump over nothing and would die long before they could melee any ranged unit in cover.-open maps (+ poor view range on strat points) allowed enemies always to sneak units behind the lines which would decap all your points before you can react.-original campaign was total boring with just 11 soldiers total instead of 100 soldierspoor pop cap + shared vehicle/infantry cap-can never controll areas because you never have enough units/turrets to cover every acces, and even if you could your army was spread tot thin-small squad sizes-game is more about microing special abilities than it is about troop composition and deploymenttypical game was over before anybody could afford a tier 3 unit.-useless minimap with oversized and ovelapping symbols, made it extremely hard to locate units when they were close to a strat point. The square structure symbol would overlap the power symbol when you build a power nod.summary of gameplay; there is no gameplay really... the only thing you do is micromanaging your squads to capture, decapture and recapture strat points, power nodes and victory points. Capture points faster than the enemy and you will win. From my experience I noticed that you quite litterly spend more time capturing stuff than to attend to actual combat. With so much micromanaging it was not even remotely entertaining to play vs an AI opponent as he would have a unit capping your points 24-7.My oppinion, this game is not even remotely an RTS game for it lacks the S part and as such it is an epic fail as a succesor to dow1. The gameplay is so horribly useless and because of the frustrating micromanaging I could not give 2 damns about the goodgraphics. If it was a standalone game I would give it 4.5/10 as DOW succesor 2.0/10

number of helpful: 3 of 13 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Stellar, absolutly fantastic. i love everything about the game!core gameplay - a straight continuation of the great Dawn of War 2 - RTS with focuses solely on unit tactics and no base building. you will have to take care of every single unit you have, position it the right way, make sure it covers the right area, and its in proper cover. use every one of your units' special abilities to turn the tide of combat. and make use of global abilities to decimate your foes.the lack of base building only enhances the experience - less focus on your off-battle base and more micro and tactics in the actual battle.what adds more to the experience is how different this game's singleplayer than the original DoW2 - instead of just starting with 4 squads and nothing more. you start only with 4 heroes and can buy additional squads and units as you progress through the level.this  makes long-term descions with what units to buy at what time and what weapon to equip them with - all the more exciting.and despite the fact that i liked the original's campegin more. this is still a fresh and exiciting way to take on the SP.now a very important note: the presentation are BLOODY AMAZING,the graphics are beutiful and every unit is very detailed. the effects of explosions, plasma shots and blood are awsome the physics of how rocks and buildngs fall apart as the battle rages on is facinating.and to top it all off, great voice acting. every unit has great responses and LOTS of them. they even respond differetly to every kind of enemy they face. the amount of detail in this game is simply unmatched. this is a must-have for every RTS fan. who cares about the base building if the combat is what really matters? if basebuilding is what you want. go play a city building game or stronghold.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												Apparently not cross-platform multiplayer. I find this very disappointing, as I got this back when I used Windows, and figured I'd be able to play it with friends who use Windows, while I'm on Linux.As for the game itself... It's a huge disappointment to a huge fan of Dawn of War 1, and the expansions for it. DoW1 was amazing. With the expansions, there were something like 9 unique races to play. It was a great RTS. DoW2 came along and wasn't even worthy of carrying the DoW name. It wasn't an RTS. It was a tactics game. It's fun for a little bit, but it's far too dumbed-down compared to DoW1. One ultra strong building producing everything, within 3 tiers. Fewer units, smaller maps, more restricted gameplay, and a cute gimmick "last stand" mode to compensate for the boring tactics play.From the perspective of an RTS fan who played the original DoW, this game was a horrible miscarriage of a sequel. But looking at the game as a standalone... It's okay; nothing special. Had the sequel been more like the original, it could have been phenomenal.

content:
Posted: March 21
												I really want to recommend this game. Trust me, I really do. But after playing with a friend for over 6 hours and completing only 7-8 missions, I've come to realize that I've completed hardly anything in my co-op Campaign. Why?The game is riddled with bugs.I've had sessions where the desync between me and my friend was horrendous and we couldn't play at all that day, then there was an issue where the mission wouldn't load... Later my friend dropped from my game which ran fine for a mission or two, and then crashed straight to desktop. Found out it was a bug regarding sound between players which basically meant that if you wanna play properly and avoid the bug, the workaround was to disable Sounds Effects volume. Like really.What the hell was the QA team for this game doing?Excuse me if I'm harsh but I work as QA too, (I immediately regret my decision), but seriously! These are freaking basic bugs that should have been sent to the devs after finding them in an easy 2 player co-op to fix them... But... Nope.I got the game on a sale for like 5 bucks, so that's cool, don't pay more than that for it, I recommend it for that price, for it's current price, however... PERFORM EXTERMINATUS.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Dark Crusade with the Annihilation mod was better than anything that came after it. Don't grab this unless you're a real WH40K buff and wanna own anything related to the franchise. Took away the fun aspects of the original DoW games and turned it into little more than a MOBA blended with a RTS. 40 points.What changed versus the original DoW series?- No more building bases, you get a single HQ with lots of HP. You call in reinforcements at this point. That means no more forward bases.- Strategic Points became Requisition Points and Power Nodes. Prepare to run your squads from one end of the map to the other to defend, because that's always fun. /sarcasm- Balance went out the window. You can basically field nothing but Tier III units and win. Eldar are even MORE hilariously overpowered than the original, but that's okay by me because I love them.- Campaign is...so...BLAND. The Risk incarnation of Dark Crusade and Soulstorm went to hell - became linear missions. Unfortunately, all the races share the same missions with vague differences here and there. Good lord, I can't even bring myself to complete it multiple times and I'm a serious achievement buff.- Certain hero types with certain wargear setups are absolutely overpowered and will wipe out entire armies rather easily. I'm looking at you, Eldar Farseer.- So few races. You got Chaos, Orks, Space Marines, Imperial Guard, Eldar and Tyranids.- THOSE DLCS! God, it's like...Borderlands 2. A more shameless money grab you will be hard pressed to find.- 2 sides. Yours and theirs. No more 8 player FFAs.+ Wargear became more interesting. They're all interchangable once purchased (with a bit of time needed to swap), so you better figure out a play style eventually and upgrade your commander accordingly. I'm referring to multiplayer of course.+ The Last Stand is fun. Also known as The Last Standalone in the steam store.Never played DoW games?Beyond the whole avoid-this-like-the-plague commentary...this is a bit of a mess. Regular gameplay (I'm talking multiplayer) involves you and your allies sharing a base on one side of the map. You get a Headquarters (once destroyed, is gone for good) along with some anti infantry turrets. You basically use your initial units and resources, go and capture a resource point to increase your resource trickle. While you're at it, go capture the enemies' (there's only 2 sides - your side and theirs) points to slow their trickle. Rinse and repeat until you have overwhelming firepower one way or another and can press the assault. It's pretty much a glorified MOBA. No idea what's with the strategy tag.Campaign involves linear missions with no real side paths. You jump on the same mission regardless of race but get vague variances here and there based on race. Maybe you can bring yourself to grind those out repeatedly, I couldn't. Campaign gameplay has no resource trickle, but to be honest your storyline heros are good enough without needing to train additional units. It's the whole 1-man-army crap all over again.The Last Stand is pretty much speaking for itself. Certainly popular enough that they made a standalone version and threw it in the steam store for like 10 bucks. Basically its you and 2 other people fighting waves and waves of enemies until you all die (think usually people explode in wave 15 or something where your enemies are all clones of the 3 of you). Amusing way of passing the time if you have friends or something.The amount of DLCs for this game is...unprecedented. It's like Relic was trying to hold on desperately to their sinking ship by throwing out cosmetic packs at high prices, knowing full well people would love to buy those. Didn't work though, their ship sank and the DoW series is gone with a horrific note.I see this mess is on sale now. As someone that lives in Australia (land of the hilariously costly games - can you say Diablo 3 for 90 bucks on release day?), 20 bucks seems decent for it I guess. Knock yourself out, but would really advise against it unless you're a serious diehard for WH40K and/or MOBA gameplay. Good thing this was a Christmas present that I could just bury under a rug somewhere.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												So is 2015 and is this game worth it?First of all for the prices YES, this thing is three games in one, with the only thing in common being that is a warhammer 40k game, and the top down perspective, but let´s see how these three games hold up.Single Player: The single player is an Almost Diablo-like Action RPG, there´s not much of troop management or what it is, is so little, the real focus is the campaign is to level up your character and get more gear, so you can stomp the oposition better, I´m not a big fan of the campaing, in fact if you´re looking for a good RTS or Strategy campaing, stay away from this, also as Diablo-like is not that great either.Last Stand: This mode, is almost like a CooP Moba game, is like that event they made for Dota 2, where you need to defend the Wrath King, like that. Is fun as hell, and addictive, as a matter of fact they made this into an standalone game you can get, if you don´t want the other two portions of the game, if you want an addictive and hard coop experience, this is the game for you. Multiplayer: Now this is my favorite part of the game, even If I´m not that good at it, it just have a great feel to it, people may say that there´s no strategy involve in this since you only spawn units and send them to fight, but they might be playing the game in the wrong way, the game is more focus on the actual fighting, and making a great fighting unit, for me this is like the Warcraft 4 that I always wanted, I like this game more than Company of Heroes or Starcraft II... I´m in love with this multiplayer, and fortunaly people still play it, there´s even a mod that expand on this, for this alone this I recommend this game.ALSO, is a great introduction to the Warhammer 40k universe.

Posted: December 25, 2012
												Breaking away from the traditions of the first Dawn of War, this second instillation of the classic and iconic RTS brings a new bold RPG element to it's gameplay. Borrowing game mechanics from hero-based strategy's such as DOTA and Leauge of Legends, Dawn of War II and it's expansions are based around hero units with special and dynamic abilites as well as a few supporting squads of infantry/vehicles. Do not be deterred by this change of pace, the action and combat is fluid and quite manageable. Loot drops and hero unit skill trees bring the player a close connection with the units on screen, and at times you'll find yourself praising whichever deity/ideal as you mow down your enemies with superior tactics!Overhauling the graphics engine, the visuals in this game have never looked better. THQ's and Relic's attention to detail with unit design, level design, and user interface is rivaled by few, and the developing duo captures the spirit of the Warhammer 40,000 universe once again! This is a must-play for Warhammer 40,000 fans, and the gameplay is very player-friendly, allowing newcomers to RTS's to learn the ropes quickly. In a nutshell: A second Dawn of War? What's not to like?!

Posted: December 17, 2013
												Campaign; Decent albeit rather linear. i.e, same campaign reguardless of Race but is understandable considering most of the development has went into the hero abilities and equipment.  Which in my opinion makes up the repetitive nature of it.Race Diversity/Balance; Tyranids caught my attention in lacking a little diversity in the fact they only have 1 hero to equip compared to the other 5 races having 4.  However, this is made up for by the Hive Lord being somewhat overpowered and 'Nids being good fun to play.Land Stand; Generally the same as the previous titles but tidied up a bit and with an awesome DLC hero, the Shas'O.Who, in my experience, is very nicely designed as he gets completely wasted in melee but the equipment options make him one of, if not THE best Damage option.Overall I feel DoW 2: Retribution is a far more accurate portrayal of how the armies should perform, based on the table top game.In comparison to the the previous DoW titles, which had some serious balance issues, mainly in having ranged units able to hold their own in melee or light/medium tanks with ridiculous health/damage.To sum up, the design of the armies in DoW 2: Retribution makes far more sense.Perhaps i'm looking at it the wrong way by basing my judgement on how accurately it reflects how the armies perform on table top, but the armies are meant to be using that as a template.That's my opinion anyway.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												A must play for any W40K or RTS fan alike! Dawn of War II: Retribution brings the final playable faction to the second title in the Dawn of War series in a smaller, tighter and intense squad-focused tactical game.The campaign's story will leave you scratching your head (for those of you familiar with your 40K lore) but the multiplayer skirmishes, Last Stand mode and Army Painter make this another notable entry to Relic's hall of fame. The CG movies are beautiful and the art and sound department go all out to put on an impressive stage.I would love to see better community-involvement support for the next title. While there are quite a number of fun mods out there, you'll find yourself craving for new maps or a better replay viewer after putting in tonnes of hours. Of course, having all the armies playable would be a nice feature too. Lots of players still play Dawn of War: Soulstorm because of that!

												Its has a easy mechanics however ever so difficult to master. The key things that well prevent you from being the best is:*Learning your play style e.g mine is using Choas Space marines with blood of khorne upgrade while using Choas cultist with grenades and terminator missiles with heavy bolters to supress enemy*Remembering what units are best for specific things and each unit in different factions. E.g Banshees from eldar, Flamethrowers in I.g and Space marines and Noise marines in choas to destroy Structures.*Adapting to fight in many different positions simulataneously.*Stopping hording armies to win like you did when you first played DOW2.*Take damn cover if possibleI do reccomend this game but when you first buy it you'll feel like it was a rip off. Thats because it takes time to realise you must adapt and stop using one type of unit for example I basically molested space marines all the time because I didn't know what other units to use and how. Also the other reason why you'll hate this game is because YOUR PLAYING ONLINE! There are 1000 players who have racked up 100's of wins and tend to be more common as they haven't given up in the game and mastered the game and start to have fun because they start to get consecutive wins. I mean I may not have the most hours but thats because I still know how new players feel like when they first play this game but I've played enough games and lost alot of games but still had my fair few in winning which means my perspective is from an average player in this game.Basically finish the tutorial it helps! Also play a few offline games before you jump in online games.

Dawn of War II: Retribution brings the final playable faction to the second title in the Dawn of War series in a smaller, tighter and intense squad-focused tactical game.The campaign's story will leave you scratching your head (for those of you familiar with your 40K lore) but the multiplayer skirmishes, Last Stand mode and Army Painter make this another notable entry to Relic's hall of fame. Posted: February 6, 2014
												This game is a wonderful addition to the wide retinue of RTS games available for the PC. It is a great introduction to the world of Warhammer 40k - it simplifies the huge amount of rules and variety in the tabletop game into a great representative RTS.What I especially loved about this game was it's huge variety of units that weren't just remodels. Much like the tabletop game, the wide variety of races and units for each race makes each match/battle unique and it is indeed a challenge to figure out counters and a strategy for a specific race against specific races.The community, though small, is tight and dedicated. There are few regulars, but their matches are very fun to watch. More fun in my opinion, than Starcraft, simply because it looks much more like a battle. Instead of a heavy focus on a player's ability to pump out APM, DoW places heavy emphasis on strategy - unit choice, retreating, maneuvers and placement are of utmost importance. The large breadth of unit compositions and hero choices add to the challenge of the game.Overall - a very good game! I only wish the community was larger!

Posted: March 12, 2016
												Retribution is a very varied and flexible RTS, with lots of replayability (especially with mods) and enough variety in game modes that in many ways it's like three or four games in one.The required planning and micromanagement makes individual units important, but is balanced well enough that the loss of an individual unit isn't fatal. There's a huge range of abilities and different playstyles for the varied races, so you can usually find a race that suits your style, and the many different commanders create a lot of potential for replayability. In terms of scale, the massive battles of Dawn of War One are long gone, so if you're expecting apocalyptic thousand-soldier battle, you'd probably be better off with Soulstorm or Dark Crusade.In terms of value for money, this game that can give you a lot of replayability even before DLC. there is a lot of DLC that oter players will have and (if you're as poor as me) you probably won't, but in PVP it's all purely cosmetic, and in the Last Stand co-op mode you'll probably just be glad to have such good teammates. The campaign is pretty much the same for each race (even the enemy races are the same, meaning that players will probably end up facing their own side at some point) so once you've played through the campaign once, there isn't that much to encourage you to come back to it. The Last Stand is probably the most replayable feature of this game, as the huge (and increasing!!!!) number of different characters that you can use in it give you plenty of reasons to keep playing. The fact that there are only two TLS maps makes it slightly less interesting after a while, but leveling up heroes and unlocking new equipment to play with has always made up for that in my view. Put it this way; people would buy a TV series on DVD for the same price as this game, and I've got a lot more entertainment out of this game (in terms of time and quality) than most TV series.Dawn of War is great fun, and while it may not be the best RTS in technical terms, the over the top sci-fi setting and variety in gameplay helps to make up for the (few) shortcomings in balance.And if you do buy this game, and decide that you don't like something about it, there's probably a mod that changes it anyway.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												DoW II: Retribution is easy to sum up.- It's somewhat buggy, and crashes a decent amount.- Balance in all modes is terrible (like in every-other DoW ever made, so what's new?)- DLC is expensive for what it is ($10 for ONE new character in Last Stand)- Single player campaign missions are copy-and-paste skirmishes.- It's netcode for multiplayer, while not the worst in history, is pretty damn close.- and I still recommend it, if only in a cautiously optimistic senseDespite all this, it still manages to be fun, especially the Last Stand mode, though if only you can manage to look past and ignore these considerable flaws.  It is also one of the only 40k games still kicking around.  There are much better experiences out there at the moment, which you might as well invest in, as the player count can get quite low sometimes, and the game can feel as though it is at the verge of extinction on a day-to-day basis (which it is).  There are always enough cool people to play with still dipping back in every now and again, whether it be for it's lop-sided competitive play, or the fun-but-heavily-flawed last stand mode.

Posted: March 11
												A little late writing a review for this game, but it had to be done given how much I've enjoyed it.First and foremost, if you want a "traditional" RTS with basebuilding, mass unit production, and hundreds of the same unit: then this is not the game for you. That aside, there are a lot of ways to play this game (campaign, singleplayer skirmish, arena multiplayer, and pvp multiplayer), so you do get a good amount of game for your money.Singleplayer:The singleplayer in this game isn't the best. For campaign, all the 6 races have the same missions, which makes it lose replayability quite quickly. Worth a play through if you enjoyed the previous DoW2 campaigns, and having your 4 heroes make their way through masses of opponents as if it were nothing is always entertaining. There is also a co-op mode, but it doens't really change anything drastically.Skirmish against the AI isn't great either, as it is not particularly strong, nor much fun to play against. Sadly I think this is just a consequence of how the game works.Multiplayer:Multiplayer is where this game shines. There are 2 very different modes in multiplayer: pvp, and "The Last Stand" (TLS), a co-op arena mode, both of which are still going (albeit with a amall nice community) years after release.In TLS, you and 2 partners will try and survive 20 waves of AI opponents. I very much enjoyed this, and while newer characters have succumbed to power creep, there are a lot of options and fun ways to play.PvP is the mode I play most these day, and while the "Find a Game" option rarely has players, I've never struggled to find a game in the public list. This sees you pit your forces against another human, usually in gaves of 1v1, 2v2, or 3v3. These move between a lot of cat-and-mouse positioning and capping in 1v1, to much more army-vs-army battles in 3v3.This is not a "traditional" RTS however, you will only have a single base structure, and a few units, with most of the figting centred around Victory Points, where holding more than your opponent will tick down the count to victory. (Sidenote: there is an alternative "annihilate" mode which focuses just on detroying the opponents base, but this has much less finesse than victory points.)On the surface this seems simple, however there is a lot of depth, and play at a high standard can be a true art form. This is not the constant scaling up of economy and unit production seen elsewhere, intead being an elaborate dance of positioning, cover, hard counter, soft counter, and abilities.This comes at a cost of it being a challenge to learn, and you may not enjoy it without a significant invesment of time playing vs other human players to get to that standard.TL:DR: Very very different from DoW1 (and if you were hugely into that, and ar elooking for DoW1v2, this is not it). However if you want something a bit different a lot of stuff out there with various different modes, and don't mind putting in a bit of time to be able to appreciate it, you will enjoy this.

Posted: July 2, 2012
												With every release of another Dawn of War the game turns more and more so into an RPG and less of a RTS. Personally I preferred the old engine, where the faction was the focus rather than the hero character which doesn't seem to provide any significant benefits that a basic squad or two of infantry couldn't make up for.The campaign is decent, though the same maps and scenarios are used for every faction as far as I can tell from playing a few Chaos and Imperial Guard missions.And of course there are a bunch of new characters for last stand which ends up taking up the majority of the time I spend in the game.All in all, a decent game worth the $7 I paid for it and the few cents spent on a couple of DLCs.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												This expansion acted as a springboard for THQ to try out Steamworks games, and as such, couldn't be set up to continue using the GFWL saves from the previous campaigns. With that in mind, the campaign here sees a lot of changes, mostly taking the gameplay backwards in design to the first DoW games where blobs of units were king. Though you can play as any race in the campaign, it's clear that a lack of focus on one race makes the game feel as if it's trying to be too many things to too many people.The multiplayer sees a few changes, mostly for the better, but the real star of the game remains the Last Stand mode, where character building stays intriguing thanks to 2 new heroes and achievement equipment that can be unlocked. It's essentially the perfect survival mode for people who like to tweak skills and see what the outcome is.

Posted: February 2, 2013
												Dawn of War II changes almost in every aspect to the first release of the franchise. While many people have been dissapointed by the course that Relic has taken for this title, I myself am delighted by the changes they applied in here:+ The gameplay changed brutally, giving DoW II much faster pace than in first game,+ We have 3 heroes at disposal for each side of the conflict; we choose our commander in accordance to our play style,+ Our commanders, as well as units, gain XP during encounters, which brings the sense of progress during every skirmish,+/- The engagement during fights is more or less counter-to-counter, meaning that each unit has strong and weak points; of course you can spam one unit and hope for adversary's lack of wit,+ Nice set of global skills for each race, charged while fighting,- The biggest struggle of this game is weak balance. If you play for some time you'll notice that in some situations you just cannot prevail, no matter how good of a player you are.I recommend this game if you like fast paced, slightly tactical and bloody RTS experience. It's totally different from Dawn of War, but it shines in it's own aspects.

Posted: April 10, 2014
												In the name of the Emperor if you are a fan of Warhammer 40k you must try this series. Retribution was sadly the last Dawn of War game before THQ died off but that does not mean the game is bad. In fact the game is one of the better ones in the series, the multiplayer is by far the best out of all the DoW2. Sadly the single player is not as good as Chaos Rising or the base DoW but it does try to change things up by allowing all the races to be played in the campaign with their own ending shown, but this does not change there isn't really much replay-ability unless you want to coop with a friend. The multiplayer mode with last stand though picks up the slack of the single player though even if you only play with computers. Since the game has been out for a while though the community is still there and active, it is not as numerous as it once was, so I recommend picking up this game when it goes on sale at some point if you want to enjoy controling squads in an RTS fashion.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												Dawn of war II: Retribution is the final RTS in the dawn of war series at the time of writing. Although the gameplay of the Dawn of War II games is vastly different from the original series it still has the same bloodied combat that made the first series a major success. The game centres around three resources; Population, Power and Requsition which all combined together provide access to new units and upgrades for current units.One of the major differences is the base building aspect is gone, although you can still build turrets etc. This means most of the tactics revolve around the new cover system which allows alot more strategic maneuvers than the previous games. Also the game punishes troop death, unlike the previous games keeping your troops alive longer and killing troops provides combat advantages aswell as bonuses to health etc.Commander units and vehicles are much more restriced in this version of the game. One commander per player from a choice of three per race which equal to Offensive, Support and Defensive to suit your tactics. The vehicles use up alot of rescources and population and are not seen in great numbers as they would in the previous Dawn of War games.However bearing in mind the changes to the Dawn of War series in the form of the II series, many veterans of the originals may not be as attracted to the game. However if you still want the blood thristy combat which the originals brought about, then this game which is the last add on for the Dawn of war II series, more than delivers.

												One of my favorite Dawn of War titles. The tactics based combat is an interesting change from base building combat even now. Multiplayer is best done with the Elite mod. Otherwise you may feel some faction imbalance and the like. Though, I'm not particularly good at the game. So, don't take my word for it. On a side note - there is a small community here. Last stand mode is far more active than the ranked multiplayer, but you will find people playing occasionally. Recommended hesistantly. Oh, and the story is good. Standard old Relic fare, what did you expect? You can play as all the races this time.

Posted: October 6, 2014
												Best graphics yet out of all the games in this series. The cap is a bit to restrictive, making it so you will not be able to get even one of each unit type during each map. It also counts turrets and other deployables making them more or less useless if you want to get to use the top tier units. The most annoying part of the game is the ability to "fall back" which makes the unit super resistant to range fire as it falls back to home base at a speed you cant match even with fleet of foot. The computer uses it so well you will often find at the end of the map you only killed 50 units. Another annoying aspect is the A.I cheats in all the little ways. It knows exactly where your suppression unit sets up and just quits going there, it knows you are throwing a grenade and will vacate area unless capping before the nade leaves your hand, knows where your fow vision line is and skirts around it. Can use these things to your advantage but is still a bit annoying to watch units constantly hit fall back the second you throw a grenade or launch your grenade launchers before the nade visual leaves your charecter. Was a great game and i recommend it, but fall back was too much and the restrictive caps didnt allow enough. You will also really miss building stuff as this just comes with one base that is prebuilt, no other buildings or construction whatsoever.

												There simply is no better or more varied RTS to be had, and it kills me that the game isn't available for OS X. Retribution, for me, is the epitome of the RTS genre: it's fast, it's hard, and it's incredibly tactical. Positioning and proper use of your skills is essential, but the reintroduction of larger squads and more macro-level gameplay really makes Retribution shine as the perfect balance between micro, macro, and hero-based play. I'd pay hundreds for a Mac port without blinking twice.

Posted: March 14, 2011
												An excellent addition to the franchise.  Retribution addresses the concerns players had about the transition from DoW and DoW2 in that it allows you to play the game with a large variable force, or with a small force of portent heros.  This flexibility as well as a few mechanical additions make this one of the best RTS/RPG combo games out there.  Well worth a look if you are interested in the Warhammer genre or RTS games in general.

Posted: April 4, 2015
												Sehr geehrte fans und evtl. Neulinge der Wh40k-Spielereihe Dawn of War - dieses Review bezieht sich ausschließlich auf den Einzelspieler-Modus in englischer Sprachausgabe und Erfahrungen, gesammelt wärend eines kurzen Ausflugs in den Modus "letztes Gefecht" (evtl. Spoiler enthalten!) Wer sich vor längeren Texten fürchtet oder Probleme mit der Konzentration hat, der kann sofort zum Ende und ans Fazit scrollen.Das Intro - kurz aber dennoch in gewohnter DoW Qualität, hat es mich direkt gefesselt und hungrig gemacht, einmal mehr als Truppführer für die Blood Ravens in das Gefecht zu ziehen.Das Hauptmenü - für einen Moment dachte ich, die anti-aliasing und Texturfiltereinstellungen sind aus. Grob-pixlig und hässlich, auch auf höchtmöglichen EInstellungen (Das Spiel wird unter Nvidia-Experience nicht erkannt, was die Option die Auflösung künstlich auf 1080p+ zu setzen zumindest über diesen Weg unmöglich macht).Immerhin wird mir ein bis dato unbekanntes Charaktermodell vorgesetzt, ein Mitglied der Inquisition - Adrastia.Kampagne-Modus Auswahl - Wow, sechs Fraktionen zur Auswahl? Genial! - Als Spieler der DoW-Serie seit 2004 allerdings, werde ich dabei aber auch direkt an DoW - Dark Crusade (2006) erinnert.Dort wurde wie ich finde, bereits sehr viel "Seele", also eine stimmige und packende Geschichte nebst Charakterentwicklung für mehr spielbare Völker geopfert. Die immer gleichen Kronus-Karten mit allen verfügbaren Fraktionen zu grinden, war mir damals bereits zu blöd. Sollte ich nun, fast 10 Jahre später eine änliche Erfahrung machen?Kampagne - Der Prolog klärt den Spieler über die Erfolge und Erlebnisse der Bloodravens innerhalb des Aurelia-Sektors auf - Ich schreibe Blood Raven, weil es unabhängig von Fraktionsauswahl immer der selbe Prolog ist, was mich etwas verwirrt. Immerhin, die ersten Minuten im Spiel lassen das Gefühl aufkommen, trotz der selben Karte doch etwas neues zu erleben.Kampagne - Hauptspiel (Als Eliphas, ehemaliger Champion der Word Bearers (Kronuskampagne), in DoW2 als Gefolgsmann der Black Legion, und nun als Sklave von Abaddon dem Plünderer anzutreffen. Was ein "Aufstieg")Tiefgreifende Dialoge und Charakterentwicklungen sind nicht zu erwarten, aber deshalb habe ich DoW auch nie gekauft - die Momente allerdings, in denen Eliphas von Abaddon kontaktiert wird, und einige Szenen mit seinem, ihm "dienenden" Chaoshexer Neroth sind äußerst amüsant! An "chuckle"-Momente aus DoW1-Winter Assault oder Auseinandersetzungen zwischen Tarkus und Avitus aus Dow2 und dem Addon "Chaos-Rising" allerdings vermag nichts aus "Retribution" anzuknüpfen.Spielgefühl - Während Deckung, die Auswahl der richtigen Fertigkeiten zur richtigen Zeit mit dem richtigen Helden (ein Wechsel zu einem nicht all-in Helden Setup war zu keiner Zeit im Spiel nötig) noch wichtig ist, so verwandelt sich das Vorgehen schon sehr bald in ein no-brainer Szenario."Alles auswählen" und Angriffsbewegung in Richtung X, dabei immer fleißig mit dem Kopf über die Tastatur rollen, um die Fertigkeiten auf cooldown zu halten. Die Option "Grid hotkeys - ON" bei der alles im WASD-Sektor abgelegt wird, macht die Sache fast schon zur einhändig gespielten farce.Ernsthaft, die größte Herausforderung als Vertreter der Chaosfraktion liegt in der Befehlsvergabe, um Kisten nach Ressourcen zu plündern. Diese Ressourcen werden natürlich in noch mehr Schaden und evtl. Energie für den von Level 1 bis 10 mit Lascannon ausgestatteten Kain investiert - mal von den zwei Missionen abgesehen, wo ich sie in jeweils einen Trupp Ketzer gesteckt habe, damit sie mir um einen Schrein von Khorne tanzen.Die Missionsauswahl wurde grafisch im Vergleich zu Dow2 - Chaos Rising wenig ansprechend gestaltet.Eine Sektorkarte mit kleinen Icons, kein toller Hintergrund - wie Beispielsweise ein von einem Asteroidengürtel umkreister Planet Typhon. Immerhin, klicke ich einen dieser winzigen Punkte an, so offenbart sich mir doch tatsächlich ein recht detailiertes Infokärtchen zum Objekt - Bevölkerungsdichte und Hintergrundinformationen, wie zum Beispiel Entwicklungen seit der Tyranideninvasion vor 10 Jahren etc. Durch dieses quasi verstecken wurde wie ich finde, eine Option für packende Inszenierung vergeudet. Nun walze ich also mit meinen seelenlosen Heretikern von einer Mission zur nächsten, und alles woran ich denken kann ist: Wann genau geht es endlich los, wo bleibt der Augenblick, an dem mich die Gänsehaut packt - wie damals, als ich von Isador Akios's Verrat überrascht wurde, oder als selbst Tarkus - mein treuer Space Marine, in der "Judgement of Carrion" von den Schrecken des Warp beinahe korrumpiert wurde.. Ich warte.Die drei zur Verfügung gestellten Skilltrees für meine Helden, und wenn nicht eingesetzt, für die sie ersetzende "Ehrenwache": Stamina "Tank" / Stärke "Angriff" / Wille "Energie u. Regeneration"Hier habe ich nach Level 3 (von 10) aufgehört zu lesen und nur noch die nächste Option gedrückt. Das einzig wichtige war, dass Eliphas's Attacken den Gegner spotten und noch mehr Energie (Energie = mehr Angriffsgeschwindigkeit/RoF) für Kain. Dieser Bursche nämlich zerlegte mir gepanzerte Einheiten noch bevor ich den Cursor über das entsprechende Ziel ziehen konnte, und das im vorletzten Schwierigkeitsgrad. Einzige Ausnahme war der mit gefühlten 10 Millionen Lebenspunkten ausgestattete Ork-Panzer in Mission X/Y.Das ich mich weder an die Mission, den Planeten/Szenario oder gar den Namen meines Widersachers erinnern kann verdeutlicht die Bedeutungslosigkeit von sich mir entgegenstellenden Feinden. Equipment - So öde und leer wie eine Welt nach dem Exterminatus, so gestaltet sich auch meine Waffenkammer.Vor meinen Augen offenbart sich die Warnung: "Dies ist die letzte Mission, es gibt kein Zurück" - und alles woran ich denken kann ist, Wow! das nenne ich mal Auswahlmöglichkeiten.. (nicht!) Zum Glück habe ich mich im Verlauf der Missionen stets für Gegenstände als Belohnung entschieden, und nicht für Truppentypen bzw. entsprechende upgrades.Kampagne - die letzte Herausforderung/Epilog. Da rennt nun also Gabriel Angelos, zuerst gefeierter und dann im Verlauf von Chaos Rising als abtrünnig erklärter und verbannter "Held" mit seinem Anti-Dämonenhammer auf den sich in einen Chaosprinzen verwandelnden Ordensmeister der Blood Ravens zu - Azariah Kyras. Und stirbt. unspektakulär. Dass daneben Jonah Orion, letzter Überlebender Psioniker des von Capt. Angelos kommandierten Schlachtkreuzers ebenfalls das zeitliche segnet, wird ebenso lieblos inszeniert. Ich habe dein Eindruck, die Entwickler wollen es an dieser Stelle einfach nur noch zu Ende bringen.. ich übrigens auch. Die an dieser Stelle nicht mehr zu leugnende Frustration meinerseits wird von dem nun folgenden "Endkampf" leider noch einmal angehoben. Das schwach entwickelte Schadensmodell für den Chaosprinzen Azariah Kyras erlaubt es nur einem Nahkämpfer wirklich effektiv an ihm zu stehen. Mein vor Seuchen und Krankheiten strotzdender Seuchenmarine "Varius" steht leider nur dümmlich in der Gegend herum und belegt Kyras von Zeit zu Zeit mit etwas Bolterfeuer - ebenso mein Chaoshexer.. Immerhin, nachdem ich die beiden in die Zweite Reihe gestellt habe, legen diese die spawnenden Chaos-Schreine und Dämonen um. Zeit für mich, einen frischen Kaffee aufzusetzen - 5 Minuten später ist es vorbei.Fazit:Mein Ziel, eine möglichst objektive und auch stärkenorientierte Wertung für DoW2-Retribution abzulegen habe ich leider nicht erreicht. Zu groß waren dafür die Unterschiede in Sachen Qualität der Vorgänger DoW1+WinterAssault und DoW2+Chaos Rising. Wer nach gut inszenierter Einzelspielerkampagne und einigermaßen anspruchsvollen Kämpfen sucht, der lässt die Finger hiervon - oder wechselt direkt in den Mehrspieler-Modus.D-fens out

Posted: February 13, 2012
												I love Warhammer 40,000. I love strategy games. Therefore, It was a no brainer that I'd love Dawn of War II and it's associated expansions, and Retribution might be my favorite, as it allows you to play the eternal underdogs of the Imperium, the Imperial Guard, in the campaign- absent since Soulstorm as a playable faction. You can play any of the included factions besides, given the game's choice of a modular campaign system a la Dark Crusade. It features many nods to earlier installments and returning characters therof, as well as some good new ones like Inquisitor Adrastia. I cannot speak for the competitive multiplayer, as such in strategy games has never been my forte. But the campaign alone is worth the price, even without the entertaining Last Stand (Which is availiable alone as a seperate purchase) gametype, which puts you and two others in control of various hero characters against waves of swarming foes. Did I mention the campaign can have 2 player co-op?

												Retribution is a funny one: The campaign is a lazy ring-in, where each and every faction is playable (excitement!) through exactly the same series of maps and via a very similar story each time (disappointment). It's still more DoW II, but nowhere near the same quality as Chaos Rising or even the original. A new arena and a few new characters are also thrown in for Last Stand (the most compelling reason for purchase in my opinion), but all in all it's a bit of a let-down. Still, if you can swing it for $10 during a sale and you enjoyed any prior entries in the series, do it and you might not regret it.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												this game is good. the main storyline is good, and fits in well with the lore of its universe. the standard multiplayer is sub-par compared to what I have seen of the previous dawn of war games, as you have a fixed base and no units that can build constructs, but is still rather fun. the last stand mode is the best part of this game, in my opinion. you and two other people are put into an arena, from a selection of two chosen by the players, and have to survive for 20 brutal rounds with an unlock system and a reset level function to get rid of your unlocks, so that you have to re-aquire them.overall, not that much to say, if you're a fan of Warhammer 40k and its universe, heavily recommended, if you have other dawn of war games, the last stand mode may be enough to get you to purchase. otherwise, you still may enjoy it

Posted: February 13, 2012
												I love Warhammer 40,000. I love strategy games. Therefore, It was a no brainer that I'd love Dawn of War II and it's associated expansions, and Retribution might be my favorite, as it allows you to play the eternal underdogs of the Imperium, the Imperial Guard, in the campaign- absent since Soulstorm as a playable faction. You can play any of the included factions besides, given the game's choice of a modular campaign system a la Dark Crusade. It features many nods to earlier installments and returning characters therof, as well as some good new ones like Inquisitor Adrastia. I cannot speak for the competitive multiplayer, as such in strategy games has never been my forte. But the campaign alone is worth the price, even without the entertaining Last Stand (Which is availiable alone as a seperate purchase) gametype, which puts you and two others in control of various hero characters against waves of swarming foes. Did I mention the campaign can have 2 player co-op?

Posted: July 3, 2011
												40K is a fascinating universe. I started out just wanting to learn about Space Marines and what was so special about them. I've read several 40K anthologies now, and enjoy the literature and history. I started playing the first Dawn Of War series and love moving my little Marines about on the map. They die a lot. I mean a LOT. Mostly because I send them without thinking into a horrible death. DOW II is fun in a different way, as you don't build structures, you take them to get the resources needed to upgrade and build your army. It's more of a squad-based focus, rather than masses of troops like the first game. Graphics are excellent, and with 6 sides to choose from, you will find at least one race to enjoy. I am a rotten multiplayer, but The Last Stand is a fun way to group with friends or matching with 2 other players to defend against ever-increasing waves of enemies. As you gain experience in TLS, you unlock better gear for your hero to increase the damage and mayhem with.

												The 2nd expansion to Dawn of War II, the squad-based Warhammer 40,000 RTS. This brings factions to six and adds super units (Land Raider etc.) to existing factions. Posted: January 2, 2015
At the time of writing I've just finished the campaign (Eldar: Very Hard) so this isn't a review of the multiplayer. Retribution is my entry point in to Dawn of War (DOW) 2 and though I'm not a fan of a lot of the changes they made to the DOW1 formula I still think this is  a great game. The amount of content provided through expansions to the original meant that it was inevitable they would have to change things up in the sequel and that's resulted in two games that stand well alongside each other. Play DOW2 for smaller skirmishes with lots of special abilities and units that gain experience. Play DOW1 for large scale warfare.A few campaign Pros and Cons that deserve mentioningCons:- Frequent bugs: They're not game breaking but you'll regularly find your heroes unable to revive each other until they walk away and come back for another try, and occasionally I had a hero fall through the ground when he died. - Balance issues: The campaign is incredibly easy even on the hardest difficulty thanks to a pretty huge design flaw. For the most part enemies don't respawn but when your units die you get a full resource refund, which means you basically have infinite units.- The directional cover system: I hate to criticise this because it's a great idea and opens lots of strategic possibilities, but the reality just doesn't work. This game mostly dispenses with the areas of cover that appeared in the previous game in favour actual pieces of terrain that units can take cover behind (or destroy). Unfortunately getting your units to do this isn't as easy as you might hope and requires an impractical amount of micromanagement.Pros- Interactive environments: Aside from the directional cover this is pretty great. You can take shelter in literally any building (or bring it crashing down if you're so inclined), demolish walls to make new pathways or send a tank in to flatten your opponents cover. - Race specific stories: The overarching narrative is the same so obviously there is some overlap but they clearly put some effort in to developing individual narratives withing that framework. The result isn't particularly memorable and the Eldar Vs Eldar section seemed quite forced, but there are also some compelling moments and it definitely adds a lot of replayability.- Looks great: They've done a great job of recreating the 40k units and the environments are colourful, varied and interesting.- Leveling up heroes and gathering loot is addictive.Edit: Skirmish mode is really good. And there are still people who play it. :)

Posted: January 28, 2012
												I've beaten all 3 of the Dawn of War 2 games. They are some of the only RTS games I can enjoy, mostly due to the much lower number of units you are tasked to control. I can actually wrap my head around the tactics, whereas your StarCraft or any other just overwhelms me. The amazing graphics, audio, and dynamic combat with full destruction certainly help things. This stand alone entry added a neat hoard mode, but these days you may be hard pressed to find low ping people to play it with. Most people just stick with the regular skirmishes online, but those are too much for me.Edit: So I got back into this to complete the last 3 campaigns, and maybe beef up my Last Stand guys mode. If you're going to only buy one of the three Dawn of War 2 games, this would be the one. It definitely has the most content. It allows you to play the campaign via 6 of the races, all with some differences in plotline. It has the better version of the Last Stand hoarde mode than the other two games. The multiplayer I can't comment on as I am terrible at RTS online, but I'm sure it's the best edition as well. I wish I knew the lore better, as I have never been a tabletop RPG fan, but I love this series so much that I'm actually listening to Warhammer 40k audio dramas to supplement this. It's just so badass. Skulls for the skull throne, and all that jazz.
